The game may instead be played by up to 8 players if players divide evenly into two teams, with each player controlling a certain number of characters in the game.

The game board is a square grid map of the Murphy Pirate base. Three scenarios are included in which the Crushers must infiltrate the base. In two scenarios, the Crushers must rescue the kidnapped scientist, Matua. In the third scenario, the Crushers must assassinate the pirate leader, Big Murphy.

The game uses an action point system, breaking away from the standard Movement Phase/Combat Phase turn order of earlier Atsutoshi Okada simulation game designs. This gave players more options for how to play their characters (by sacrificing movement in order to invest more time in attacking, for example), but was not quite satisfactory to Okada (as per Crusher Joe rule book designer's notes). This action point system would later inspire and evolve into Okada's "Action Pattern" mechanic, which debuted in Macross: City Fight (as per Macross: City Fight rule book designer's notes).
categories: Fighting, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction

name: Monster Maker: Dragon Treasure
description: One of the few Monster Maker games that does not use cards, this is a hex-and-counter boardgame. The object of the game is to get back the treasures the Dragon has stolen. The first player to get the 3 treasures and return to the castle is the winner.

name: Monster Maker: Dungeon Wars
description:
Fantasy board game based off the Monster Maker card games. This one is still card-heavy, as it uses cards for spells and some events. The board it made of of 4 boards that each show a corridor section with rooms and get put together to make a large map that varies each game.

The game includes 4 metal figures for the player characters.

name: EPYX Play Action VCR Football
description: Players roll a die and consult charts to determine results. Players choose offense and defense cards which give results or refer to VCR tape.
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Metanon: The Biocode Adventure
description:
Metanon: The Biocode Adventure: A Fun Way to Teach Kids about DNA!

Imagine that you're a space traveler whose ship has been forced to land on the planet Metanon. Your computer is damaged, and your ship is leaking fuel and oxygen. To complete your mission and return home, you will need to find three missing items and put them in your spaceship. Sound simple? Not so fast. You can get them only by entering three walled cities. To do that, you must collect Biocodes, and put them together in the right sequence and pattern combinations that unlock the cities' gates.

Biocodes and Brain Development:
(serious stuff for parents and teachers)

DNA keeps making headlines. Kids may not be ready to learn the difficult terminology, but Metanon:The Biocode Adventure prepares them to grasp the basic concepts of DNA. All players use the game's biocode pieces in different combinations. Why is this shape and color matching important? Just by playing the game, kids begin to understand how DNA works. This form of learning is one of the most effective ways of preparing young brains. The critical skills learned in Metanon:The Biocode Adventure help kids excel in school and ultimately in life.

At kSERO Corporation, Inc. we create games that help young children develop their cognitive and analytic skills. Our games are designed and tested by noted scientists and educators, using the latest discoveries in FUN and brain research.
mechanics: Pattern Building, Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: WWII Skirmish
description: Skirmish is a basic introduction to wargaming. Think of it as a game of chess on steroids. When most wargames fall short of enjoyment because of game length and complexity (Most last between 6-80 hours and take even longer to learn) we have kept this game simple and enjoyable so it can be learned and played in as short as 15 minutes. Of course we have longer scenarios too for those of you who enjoy a longer game! Various game scenarios are included with an open-ended ability for you to add your own, making it a game guaranteed never to collect dust on your game shelf!
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Simulation, Variable Player Powers

name: Monster Collection
description:
A fantasy collectible card game with many of the same themes as Magic: The Gathering. You have a bunch of monsters that you move along land that it set between the two players (with the monsters actually on the land, unlike Magic, but somewhat like the CCG 'Guardians').

Was fairly popular, with at about 4 expansions before a sequel was produced.
publishers: Bushiroad Inc., Group SNE, Kadokawa Shoten

name: Dragoons in the Donjons
description: Instead of a few adventurers entering a dungeon to fight monsters, in this game, a militia goes down into the dungeon. That militia is composed of the likes of pikeman and infantry.

name: Lemlican Series 3: Arms Collection
description:
Final part of an ambitious 3-part attempt to make an RPG card game. This set provides many weapons, as well as various cards meant to make it also playable stand-alone.
However, it was really meant to be used with the others in the 3-part set.

Expands

Lemlican Series 1: Lemlican Musketeers Card RPG
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy

name: Monster Maker: Space Trader
description: The Monster Maker characters in a science-fiction theme. The game remains similar to the later games in the Monster Maker series, with player, monster, and treasure cards (but of course, no corridor cards).

name: Golfer's Dominoes
description: Golfer's Dominoes is a companion set to Dr. Miller's Golf Ace, with similar packaging and somewhat jocular, quirky rules, but there the similarity ends. Dominoes is, mechanically, a much simpler game, based on playing the most advantageous domino depicting one of seven possible golfing situations, from your hand of 4. The 28 dominoes are made of stiffened card and bear simple cartoon-style drawings of a golf ball lying on the fairway, beside a bunker, in a bunker, beside water, in water, beside the hole and in the hole. The player managing to place legitimately an "in the hole" domino with no hazard domino showing on any of the four ends of the pattern wins the hole. There is no counting of "strokes". The victor is simply the one who wins most holes.

name: Domino's Pizza Delivery Game
description:
Players are competing Domino's Pizza drivers who draw orders and attempt to deliver them in time. And naturally, it comes in a box that looks like it could hold a pizza...

From the rules:
"The DELIVERY GAME is genuinely realistic and exciting to play. Driving situations that occur are everyday encounters taken from real life situations. Both licensed and unlicensed drivers will enjoy the opportunities for success and the challenges faced by the delivery person. Game participants will develop safety awareness, rules of the road knowledge and a better "driver" attitude while having fun trying to win!"
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Pick-up and Deliver, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Wall Street Game
description: Wall Street Game simulates the international stock market scene for players to speculate in. The goal is to amass the greatest fortune as the players buy and sell shares on 17 bourses such as in New York, London, Frankfurt, Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Moscow. Currency exchange also comes into play as the players can trade in US dollars, the Deutschmark, and in gold bullion. During play, prices on the indices will fluctuate and possibly crash.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Stock Holding

name: Rat-Mal
description:
An array of tiles is placed on the table - with pictures of many different things - hat, bell, igloo, sun, tent, and so forth. One player hides a counter under one of the tiles. The others ask questions about the location of the secret counter, and remove tiles they decide it is not underneath. For example, "Is it under something that can fly?" being answered "no" would eliminate the butterfly and airplane.

The goal is to find the hidden counter.

name: Murder à la carte: A Taste of His Own Medicine
description:
"Revenge, fear and greed stalk the corridors of Headline Hall in the summer of 1947, as six people gather to hear Michael "Monty" Montague announce his plans for Montague Enterprises. One of the six murders Monty by poison, but was the poison meant for someone else...?

You and your guests will play the roles of these six characters. Suspicion and deceit will dominate the evening as you each use your powers of detection and subterfuge to interrogate the other characters and prove your own innocence. But one of you is the murderer...and only one person has worked out the identity of the murderer -- Dr. Jock McClew, the detective in charge of the case. He has recorded some pieces of information that will help you in your hunt for the murderer, so remember to heed his warnings well!"

Contents:
- Costume suggestions and recipe ideas
- Party instructions
- 5 Invitations and envelopes
- Name tags
- 6 Character handbooks
- 6 Secret clues
- Cassette tape
publishers: Endurance Games Ltd., Paul Lamond Games Ltd, Prism Leisure Corporation PLC

name: Nummerus Zahlus
description:
Disks bearing the numbers 1 through 48 and a selection disk are shuffled and placed in an irregularly-shaped grid. Players move the selection disk like a Chess queen, capturing the first number disk along the selection disk's move. If no such capture can be made the player may move the selection disk to any space containing a number disk.

When all 48 number disks are captured the player with the longest chain of sequential numbers (i.e., 13-14-15-16) wins. The game can also be played for points, where chains score points based upon their length. There is also a trading variant, in which twice during the game players can force a trade of a piece for a unconnected piece of another player.

In the solitaire game players try to have only chains of six of more pieces, and cannot merge chains.

The ASS edition appears to be identical to the GAMES edition except that in the four-player trading variant players can only trade once, and a "49" disk is included for some reason.
mechanics: Grid Movement, Set Collection, Square Grid

name: Bastard
description:
Based off the strangely named anime of the same name, this is a fantasy dungeon exploration game most similar to 'Dungeonquest', and like that game, it is fairly luck (and dice) dependant.

The game uses a board filled with squares that the room tiles are secretly placed on. There are 5 scenarios included with the game, each with different objectives for winning the game. One is "Hydra", where the object is, what else.. to kill the Hydra. Battle Royale is a fight to the death in the dungeon. One has you placing a flame sword in the middle of the dungeon and then getting out. One has you trying to rescue 'Yohko' and get back out of the dungeon, and the last has you trying to get 'Satan's Ring' and escape from the dungeon with it.
categories: Exploration, Fantasy, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Kreuz und Quer
description:
Kreuz und Quer is played on a 17x17 board. 2 Players try to move their 3 musketeers and 8 soldiers to the other side of the board, using two dice:
First, the red dice indicates mandatory backward or sideways movement of one unit, followed by mandatory forward movement from the green dice. Soldiers move orthogonally, musketeers can move diagonally as well. Musketeers count double at the end of the game.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Thrice
description: A round is three rolls of five 30-sided dice with letters on them (26 letters + 3 wilds +1 wild vowel). Each player chooses where to fill in the letters on their own work sheets - everyone uses the same letters, but assigns them in secret. These choices limit you as the round goes on. You can leave gaps in your words, hoping the next roll will fill them in. You also have an initial pool of letters you can use to fill in blanks. Only complete words score.

name: Generations
description:
The Game of Family Knowledge

This is a party game intended for play by families. Each team tries to answer questions about their own family; the best ones are those where one player has to write down his answer to a personal question, then everyone else tries to guess what his answer was. Good for a light fun time at a family get-together.

name: Alphabok
description:
This rare game by Springbok - the "Puzzle People" - is a Solitaire Word Game created by John O. Nilan and published in 1968-69. The object is to start with a "Key Phrase" running vertically on the board, then "build" words from left to right from the Key Phrase - continually building and re-building until you use all 200 letters. There is even a Double Alphabok game which can be played by two players.

Complete game includes: Board (w/Non-Slip surface), 48-Page Instruction book (Includes 12 pages of rules, tips, Key Phrases and examples with remaining pages for recording completed games), plastic Sorting Platform/Holding Tray(also holds board & instruction book) and at least 200 Letter Squares (With Non-Slip backing to prevent sliding on board - Game only calls for 200 Letter Squares, but the game usually had extras included).

name: Territory
description:
The Great Father-of-All was worried. An argument occurred in the Heavens about which God should be given the newly created world. So he decided to make the Four Pillars of God compete for sole power of the world. it would be the God who could use the power from the secret Mighty Jar most suitably, and expand his territory most widely. It is said the world was completed in seven days.

Imported from Japan, this abstract promises to be interesting.

name: Straightaway
description: "A new look at the high-speed world of Grand Prix auto racing. Cars, drivers, the color and excitement of the race itself, with an important plus. Sponsorship of racing cars is big money business for the corporations and individuals who produce automotive parts and products. Now is your chance to be the heavy-spending sponsor of some of the world's fastest racing machinery. Through a new computer-type format you watch your drivers duel through lap after lap of flat out excitement, with your money riding on every down shift, power slide and switchback. An authentic and fascinating way of enjoying the thrills of official Grand Prix racing."

name: Screwball: The Mad, Mad, Mad Game
description:
Every player or 'Boob' is in the "MADvertising business" on MADison Avenue. He drives his Jokeswagon along the path, collecting "clients" and slogans. Meanwhile he spends his Mad Money.

First Boob to lose all his Mad Money ends the game and he is the winner.... Unless... the richest of the remaining players holds in his hand the "Madly Rich" slogan - this player is then declared the winner.

Supposedly this game was at the center of a Mad Magazine lawsuit which Transogram lost. I haven't been able to find anything substantiating this.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Guilty Party
description: You and your friends are the participants in the trial of David Defendant. The charge is MURDER TWO. After the attorneys and witnesses are finished with all the testimony all of you will become a jury to determine whether or not David was convicted or not. The testimony (facts) change from game to game so it's never the same.

name: Play the Game
description:
"Play the Game. The book you can play. Complete with counters and detailed rules."

"Welcome to the exciting world of Board Games! From the earliest known board game in the English language, A Journey Through Europe, invented in 1759, through Edwardian England's Golden Age of Games, to the mid-20th Century, you will travel 300 years of history and pleasure. There are great new experiences for aficionados, as well as intimate games for two and party games for many."

This book includes color photos of the boards from 46 vintage games. Rules are included, along with a sheet of pieces to cut out, so that all of the games may be played.

List of games included
publishers: argos press, BCA: Book Club Associates, H. Proost & Cie, Michael Joseph Ltd, Reed Books

name: Nimble Numbers
description:
This is a tile laying game that has math at its base. The object of the game is to be the first one to get rid of your numbers by making examples. There are three kinds of tiles: Number tiles from 0 to 9, equal sign tiles, and math function tiles (+, -, X, and /).

At the start of the game the number tiles are randomly drawn by the players until they have all been drawn. The function tiles are left face down to be drawn one at a time when its your turn.

On your turn you try to make a math equation using your number tiles and the function tile that you drew this turn.

Example you have numbers 0, 1, 4, 6 in your hand and you draw a + tile. On your turn you would pick up an = tile and then play 4 + 6 = 1 0. The next player would then build off of the original equation either horizontally or vertically.

name: Trivial Pursuit Mini Pack: War & Victory
description: This Mini or Pocket Pack was made for use with the Trivial Pursuit Pocket Player Set Game but also featured color coded questions for use with the regular Trivial Pursuit games. This set contains 120 questions about war and battles.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Party Game, Trivia

name: Husband at Large
description:
Unusual chase game. One player plays the part of the husband, and others are relatives and friends of his wife. An elusive spouse appears and disappears from the board as other players roll dice to move about and see if they can land on the space where the husband is hiding.

Winner is either the husband or everyone else. Husband is also given a level depending on when (and if) caught: Aimless Amateur, Deflated Don Juan, Fearless Fugitive, Rueful Romeo, Careless Casanova, or Playboy at Large.

Very 1960's, but still amusing today.
mechanics: Hidden Movement, Roll / Spin and Move, Team-Based Game

name: Columbus Was Wrong
description:
In Columbus Was Wrong, players compete by trying to sail from Spain to India and back. However, there is a twist: they must do so without sailing off the edge of the world.

The major components include an antique globe with two movable disks suspended around the equator, twelve small plastic ships (3 per player), and the dice that determine movement. Each player has only one ship on the board at a time; the remainder are a reserve to be drawn upon if needed.

Players uses their turn to advance his ship and rotate the board based on his die roll. Certain spaces will allow a ship to move closer to the globe; others force the player further out. If a ship is force to sail off the edge of the board, the player tries again with a fresh ship in Spain. A player who runs out of ships is out of the game.

name: Treasure Island
description: This Milton Bradley game #4037 featured an unusual way of determining how many spaces to move during a turn. You determined your move by snapping wooden disks from red circular spaces on the four corners of the board into the numbered sections on the right and left margins. If your button landed between two movement squares then you moved the total of the two squares. The object of the game was to obtain the most pieces of eight by moving a man over the various colored circular spaces, from the starting space to the finish.

name: Deluxe Pinball Soccer
description: Players try to get as many balls into the opponent's goal while preventing balls from entering your own. Like in pinball, each player controls 2 flippers to move up to 24 balls around the play area. The miniature plastic soccer balls are dropped into chutes, ramps and funnels before the game starts. Feeder mechanisms release the balls into action. The winner of Pinball Soccer is the player with the fewest number of balls in his or her goal. Takes five minutes to assemble. No batteries required.

name: Fantasy Manager
description:
aka David Baddiel & Frank Skinner Fantasy Manager The Board Game

Baddiel & Skinner are a pair of sit-down comics who turned a 90's craze for fantasy soccer management games into a hit TV series for a few of years. Players take the role of football managers, buy & trade players, check a table of stats to see how they perform over the season and try to win the league. The TV show had little to do with the actual fantasy management game and this game has nothing to do with the TV show, being more related to the computer games of the 80s.
categories: Economic, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Sports

name: Fire, Hack & Run
description:
"Universal Skirmish Rules for all periods up to the 1880's, including Fantasy. Fast and playable, includes all the detail to cover any situations in a small scale action. Also perfect for western gunfights. Each miniature figure represents a single warrior. The scale of Fire, Hack, and Run is 1 centimeter equals 1 yard. This scale is easily playable and realistic for use with 25mm or 30mm figures."

"Encounters between single opponents and small groups of armed soldiers are entirely different from large scale battles in more ways than just the obvious. The basic factors are really the same whether the combatants are French lancers clearing a wood of Russian Jagers, Fuzzy Wuzzies attacking British regulars in the Sudan, Roman legionnaires facing German barbarians in a forest, or even dwarves in combat with a troll in a cavern - all of these combatants share many of the same problems and difficulties."

"Contains 2 single sided card stock character sheets."
categories: American Civil War, American Indian Wars, American Revolutionary War, American West, Ancient, Fantasy, Medieval, Miniatures, Napoleonic, Post-Napoleonic, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Events, Line of Sight, Paper-and-Pencil, Role Playing, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game, Simulation, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Space Future
description:
From the box:

A team of space explorers are on a common, dangerous mission. You set up the mission. As in real space. each person has an important part to fulfill and must return safely to Earth. Each must use the craft, equipment & fuel wisely. Keep an alert mind on the controls. Lives are at stake. We have to look after one another, performing daring rescues. A special feature is that players are not static, but grow in wisdom and knowledge. This personal growth affects how well you perform during the mission. A quick moving game with plenty of strategy decisions.

name: Tudor Joust
description:
A variant of Dou Shou Qi and L'Attaque; although very similar to L'Attaque this game has more in common with Dou Shou Qi.

You have eight pieces, six knights, strength eight down to three, A Herald, valued at two, and a trumpeter, valued at one. A piece can capture any piece with a lower value. However a trumpeter will lose to any piece which attacks it but will defeat the number eight knight if it attacks. If two knights of the same strength meet the attacker wins.

Like in Dou Shou Qi the trumpeter (the Rat in Dou Shou Qi) is the only piece allowed to go through the fenced off areas (the river in Dou Shou Qi). However, unlike in Dou Shou Qi, it is the seven and eight knights (the Elephant and Lion in Dou Shou Qi) who can jump over the fenced off areas.

The game is essentially what R.C. Bell has described as the Jungle Game. The theme has just been changed from jungle animals to knights. See The Board Game Book, or Board and Table Games from many Civilizations.

name: Dexter's Laboratory: The Incredible Invention Vs Dee Dee
description:
Dexter is on a quest to complete his greatest work. As soon as he can collect the six parts he needs, it will be a fine day for science! On your turn, you roll the special game die and move your Dexter towards the center of the game board to collect the parts you need. If you are feeling lucky, once you have picked up one part, you may want to continue and collect a second part before heading back to your lab...

But that can be a a daring decision! When a player rolls Dee Dee, he or she decides whether to move their Dexter or to activate Dee Dee. If they decide to let her loose (oh no!), they swing her around the pole and any Dexter she knocks over - even their own - has to give back whatever parts he is carrying and return him to his starting position


Be the first to collect all six cards, and your contraption is complete....OOOH!...you win!
categories: Action / Dexterity, Movies / TV / Radio theme
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Spacefarers
description:
A very early offering from Games Workshop, and apparently an ancestor of what would become Warhammer 40,000, Spacefarers is "a set of science fiction skirmish rules designed specifically for the Spacefarers range of figures manufactured by Citadel Miniatures Ltd... The rules have been designed for two players to carry out small scale skirmishes with each player in control of a unit of Imperial Marines, Dark Disciples, Star Patrolmen, or independent gangs."

Most of the rules are pretty standard tabletop miniature skirmish rules. Each unit may move a certain number of inches per turn, may fire a ranged weapon, and/or engage in close combat with models in close proximity. No grid is used for movement, a ruler is used to measure linear distances.

Unlike the massive armies sported by the game's descendants, Spacefarers focuses on single squads, and allows for more detail, such as rudimentary hit location, along with different armor protection for each location, and individually equipped models. The game appears to have much more in common with games like Necromunda or Mordheim in this respect.

The rules are short, only 44 pages, with sparse hand-drawn artwork; not a single photograph is used. Two introductory scenarios are included, rules are included for constructing your own forces. Depending on which force you choose to represent, you get a certain amount of "money" to use to buy equipment, and the rules indicate how large your squad will be (in one case, it's random!).

name: Gouwan Strike
description:
A baseball game that concentrates on the pitcher/batter match up. Each pitcher has 6 types of pitches they can throw. The pitcher selects a pitch card and places the card face down (the batter will only know if it's a 'slow' or 'fast' pitch), and places the ball on a square representing the location of the ball. The batter choosing to let the ball pass (if he thinks it'll be a ball), to bunt, or swing. To swing, he places the bat over 4 locations where he thinks the ball may end up. The pitcher then reveals the pitch, and rolls a die to see how many spaces and what direction the pitch moves to determine the final location of the pitch. Curve balls will move a few spaces inwards, a sinker downwards, and so on.

If the ball is hit, the batter rolls a die, and adds a bonus based on which of the 4 locations he covered the ball was thrown to (he may have a +4 to any pitch thrown to the upper right location, but no bonus for the other three squares, for example). For the most part, the higher the roll the better, and you get the results for the hit, such as double play, hit, double, and so on.

The sixth in Grapac Japan's series of games under the label "Aeronaut". They are meant to be very fast playing (around 15-30 minutes). They all come in a file-type holder, with the inside of the file being the game board, and all of the components attached to the ring binder in bags and pouches.

name: Monster Parade
description: Monster Parade shows a series of monsters (repeated several times throughout the deck, with different colors and favorite foods). Each player receives nine cards, revealing the first and placing it in front of them. Players then simultaneously pick up their remaining cards and try to build a parade in front of them by playing cards to the left or right of previously-played cards by matching either the monster, the monster color, or the favorite food. Cards may also be played on opponents' parades using the same rules. The first player out of cards is the winner.
categories: Animals, Card Game, Children's Game, Real-time

name: TOM: The Origins Metagame
description:
Cards for this CCG were distributed for free at the 2002 Origins convention. Each card depicts a real game, creator/gaming personality or company. (The cards are paid ads.)

Players secretly select cards from their collection and simultaneously reveal them. Normally a company beats a person, a person beats a game and a game beats a company. However, if one card lists the other (i.e., the person worked for the company) then the victory is reversed. Ties are broken according to the star, diamond and shield stats on the cards. (Compare stars, diamonds and shields in that order until the tie is broken.) The star statistic is dependent on the Origins awards and is equal to nominations + 2*wins + 5*hall_of_fame_listings. Every autograph on the card that matches a name listed on the card is worth an additionally 5 stars.

The second set of cards should appear at the 2004 Origins convention (the 2003 Origins convention was supposed to have the second set, but there were problems). Cards for inactive games, companies and designers can be requested cheaply.



Awards
2002 Origins Award Nominee: Best Trading Card Game.

name: I Giochi del 2000: Dream team
description:
This is a basket management game. Players take the role of basket managers, buy & trade players, check newspaper votes each week to see how they perform over the season and try to win the league.

The booklet belongs to "I giochi del duemila" ("The games of 2000") collection: a serie of role-playing games, gamebooks, wargames, card games and so on that included 23 titles. The name of the collection refers both to the end of the millenium and to the price: 2000 liras, that means 1.03 euros, making them the cheapest games in Italy.

name: Schwarz-Rot-Gold
description: The game is played on a 3x4 grid with pieces in three colors (black, red, and gold, natch). Each player has 6 pieces in each color and places one per turn. The object is to create lines of 3 pieces in the title sequence (black-red-gold). The lines can be created orthogonally, diagonally, or vertically, since the pieces stack up to 3 high. Creating a line allows you to take a piece from your opponent, and whoever runs out of pieces first loses.

name: Good Dog Carl: the Game
description: A game based on the classic children's book. The game components are four puzzle sets of 8 pieces each. Each set depicts an illustration of Carl the Dog taking care of Baby at day care, in the park, at a masquerade ball, and at a birthday party. The object of the game is to put together your 8-piece picture before the other players do.

name: Genesis Climber Mospeada
description:
Alternate name: "Robotech: The New Generation"

Complexity level 3 on Tsukudas 1-6 scale (1=easiest)

Based off the Genesis Climber Mospeada anime that was edited into being 1/3rd of "Robotech" in America (the Invid Invasion/New Generation). The mecha in this game are motorcycles that can turn into robots (non-sentient; piloted by humans).

2-player hex & counter style wargame. Includes 3 map boards and 468 counters.
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction, Wargame
mechanics: Hexagon Grid, Line of Sight, Movement Points, Ratio / Combat Results Table, Simulation

name: Appleseed
description:
A box set detailing the world of Appleseed for use with the "WARPS" (Wild Adventure Role Play System) game. This is not a complete game in itself.

While it does count more as a role-playing game, it does include counters and a map, and has more of a board game feel than 'table talk' RPGs.
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction

name: Mobile Suit Gundam: Char's Counterattack
description:
"The tactical combat and Role Playing game in Gundam world"

Includes two rulebooks, one for using the contents of the box for a beginner-level wargame, and one for using it as an expansion to the "WARPS" (Wild Adventure Role Playing System) game. Other contents include 2 data charts, pilot character sheets, 6 maps, a sheet of counters, 2 six-sided and 2 ten-sided dice, and well as a counter tray.

This is based off the Mobile Suit Gundam anime series and is part of the Mobile Suit Gundam family of games.
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction, Wargame

name: Sacrifice in the East
description:
"Sacrifice in the East is a two-player game based on the final months of World War Two where the Soviet Army finally ejected German forces from the Soviet Union. The portion of the battle simulated here represents a nightmare delaying action as German forces tried futilely to prevent the avenging Red Army from penetrating Germany during the final days of World War Two. In the game, one player controls German forces while the other player controls the Soviet forces."

This 10 semi-monthly turn game starts in Dec II, 1944. It has an 8.5"x11" b&w map of the Polish portion of the eastern front totaling 191 hexes. 88 colored counters need to be mounted for play.

Panzerschreck Magazine, Issue 7, Winter 2001-02.

name: Frigates!
description: "Beat to quarters and clear for action when you take command of one of America's famous fighting warships. Sail the U.S.S. Constitution or the U.S.S. Constellation into combat against ships of the British and French navies. Watch the wind and gain the 'weather-gauge' in seven different detailed ship-to-ship battles from 1798 to 1815."
categories: American Revolutionary War, Educational, Nautical, Wargame

name: Swingo
description: This is more a collection of games.There is a special die in the game. This die is mechanical and rotates at an fixed point. There are windows to look through. And it depends on how you prepare the die if you see numbers or letters. Comes with different game rules.

name: Het Zuiderzeespel
description: Every player is a ship owner. They go from haven to haven, always trying to be the first one. At the haven is a card. This card tells you where to go next. The weather is also defined by cards. The ships react to the weather. There are also cards with different events. Sometimes you have to wait one round perhaps while you eat food as an example. If you finish the goal on your haven card you earn money. You can receive your money in ship improvements so that your ship works better in bad weather conditions. The game ends when the first player earns 1000 Taler.

name: Briljant
description: Players are dealing with jewelry. There are 48 of these in 6 different colors. All colors have a different rang shown on the small board. On each turn players draw one and decide if they keep it or put it on the gameboard. If they put it on the gameboard the price/rang gets lower. Player with the most valuable jewelry wins.

name: Battlefront: World War II Air Warfare
description:
The game is designed around the concept of each player controlling up to a flight of aircraft (3-5 planes). The rules contain sufficient complexity and detail to make games with only one plane interesting. The rules cover fighters and ground attack aircraft from 1939-45.

Scale:
1 model represents a single fighter
1 hexagon represents 200m horizontally and 12.5m vertically
Each move is 2.5 seconds of combat.

This is essentially a set of miniatures rules that are designed to be played on a hex grid with either models or counters.
categories: Aviation / Flight, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II

name: Pass the Buck
description:
A nicely produced and packaged Hearts variant.

The cards are in four colors (acting as suits), with values 1-10, 15, 20, 25, and 50. Red cards are bad to take in tricks, with a degree of badness equal to their numerical value. The purple 20 (the "Bad Buck"), if taken in a trick, *doubles* your ultimate score for the hand (ouch). The player with the most points loses the hand and decrements a six-sided die (thoughtfully provided) to keep track. When any player loses six hands, the game ends and the player with the most hands not-lost (whatever) wins.

name: Wacky Races: Card Game
description: Based on the Cartoon of the same name with Dick Dastardly etc. This game is based on the Uno rules however it has some added twists. Each player is also trying to get his car to the front of the race before playing his last card. Most cards change the race order in addition to the usual Uno effects. The version I have is Japanese. There are some cards that need translation!

name: Maehmohri Sat.1 Comedy
description:
This is Memory but with some special cards. There is the Arschkarte: you give this one to another player. That player has to give away half of his already collected cards.
Vollselberendverarschkarte: If you draw this card you have to give half of your cards to your left neighbor.
Rinderwahnsinnkarte: Players change their seats but have to leave their cards.
Joker: it is your turn again.
Aetsch/baetsch Karte: There are no matching cards for these cards so players lose their turn.

name: Meet
description: Move your 3 pieces across the board. You place your movement chips (1 to 3 points) on the board. these are now obstacles for the rest of the game. The game ends when one player manages it to bring his pieces to opposite corner (not really possible to win the game by doing this) or the be last one who can move.

name: Edgehill 1642
description:
English Civil War battle, designed to be played like a "miniatures" game. Components consist of: an 11-inches by 17-inches Mapsheet; 118 THIN die-cut counters; Order of Battle Sheet; 2-page Rules; Fire & Melee Tables; & a Rules(errata) Supplement. Players must provide their own DICE-looks to mean at least 6--6-sided type needed(it depends on the ODDS).
The mapsheet is overall TAN with BLUE & GRAY print. There are Clear, Rough, Brush, Town, Road, & River hexes plus the TURN Record Track is printed on the game map. The game counters are THIN RED, & YELLOW with ORANGE stripes while representing King Charles, Essex, Baggage, Dragoons, Cavalry, Artillery, Pikemen, & Musketmen. Use a blank for the Turn Record Track as the Game lasts 8 turns.
The unique aspect of MELEE Combat resolution is that it occurs in the SAME hex & BOTH players roll dice. NO matter how many dice are rolled by either player, ONLY the Highest die is chosen for comparison. There are also MUSKET and Artillery FIRE/Reload Rate Tables, which takes place at a distance including adjacent.
categories: Civil War, Fighting, Pike and Shot, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Hexagon Grid, Ratio / Combat Results Table, Simulation

name: Disney Adventurers
description:
A Disneystore exclusive game. From the rules book:

Select your favorite character (Aladdin, Tarzan, Peter Pan or Hook) and overcome challenges as you travel around the board. Defeat the other Adventurers who stand in your path and race them to the finish. Travel around the board collecting a different character card each time you reach a character base. The first player to collect all 5 character cards, ending with Hercules, wins the game!
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Laß die Kirche ins Dorf
description:
1580. The colonization of the country proceeds rapidly. Also the population increases rapidly. The first settlers are not only followed by dealers and scoundrels but also by the church. Soon a new bishopric will emerge.

Laß die Kirche im Dorf is a strategy game for 2-4 players. By placing fields an abundant landscape emerges with fields of wheat and lakes that can be cultivated by the farmers and building sites on which farmhouses and churches can be built.

Goal of the game is to become bishop. The player who attracts the most followers to his churches becomes bishop. This happens by building churches near farmhouses. Adjacent churches however compete for the favor of the followers. The number of collected followers thus fluctuates occasionally.

name: Whodunnit
description: A deduction card game that's a bit like Cluedo without the board. Motive has been added to the things to find out about the crime. Players take turns asking if a player has a two cards, this player reveals if they have one of them. Play continues until someone deduces the missing 4 cards.

name: Hoplite Warfare
description:
Hoplite Warfare (650-330BC) tabletop Miniatures rules

These rules are designed to simulate the warfare of Archaic and Classical Greece, from the rise of the Hoplite (along with the polis as the typical political unit in Greece) to his eclipse by other systems and the decline of the polis as an important institution. By extension, the rules also cover areas and times where other races were equipped as and fought in the same style as Hoplites; The rules will also cover races and civilizations which clashed with Hoplite armies.

The period of Hoplite domination in the Mediterranean we have taken as beginning c.675 B.C. However, there can be no set date for the end of the Hoplite. In the Eastern Mediterranean world we have taken the battle of Gaugamela 331 B.C.; in Italy we have taken c. 386 B.C. when at the Allia a Roman Hoplite-style army was defeated by Gauls, signaling the end of Hoplite tactics in Italy; but in Sicily Hoplites still seem to have been dominant till the time of Agathokles (d. 285 B.C.). Thus, unlike the established ideas in ancient wargaming, these rules are restricted to a narrow time span and a limited geographical area. They do not pretend to universalize, nor are they immutable dogma — they may be adapted to suit the individual wargamers research.

name: Pony Soldiers: Skirmish Rules for the Indian Wars & the Old West
description:
Published in Basin City, WA with assistance by the Every Other Tuesday Night Gamers & War Eagles Gaming Society. Can be used with 15mm appropriate figures, players will need to provide at least 1 6-sided DIE for each player, a 6-Ft. Tape measure, a Protractor for determining Gunfire & Observation, Artillery Facing changes, Gatling Gun Firing Arcs, and Cannon & Howitzer firing arcs.

It is suggested that players provide Figures for their characters in the following positions: on Horseback; on Foot; Kneeling; Prone. I would also suggest Figures displaying various armaments such as Pistol wielding, Rifle Armed, Knife or Sabre displayed, etc. The Rules CAN also be used for 25mm Figures and there are annotations in ( ) for this scale. There are Character Record, Artillery Record, and Horse Record Sheets which will have to be copied in order to provide enough for everyone. It is suggested that each Player control no more than 6 Characters per playing. There is a Pregenerated Character List to help gets things started quickly, but most folks will want to create their "own" Old West figure they have in mind. Players will find a Regional Map of the Plains section of the U.S.A. with various Native Areas located upon it and State's borders with numerous Forts & Towns of the "Old West". There is even a "Detail" map of an imaginary "Old West" area for assistance in starting up a Campaign for whatever the player's desire. The Back Pages of the Rules Booklet contain Movement Charts, Movement Modifiers, Skill Challenge Damage Chart, Observation Modifiers, General Skill Challenge Modifiers, Missile Combat Chart, Melee Combat Chart, Campaign Observation Modifiers, and Weapon & Range Chart.

The Sequence of Play is as follows: 1.Initiative; 2.Movement; 3.Observation; 4.Missile Combat; 5.Melee Combat; 6.Artillery Fire; 7.Static Actions. NOT all of these will be followed since not everyone will be using some such as Artillery everytime. During Static Actions, players will do anything NOT covered in previous phases, such as Draw Weapons, Reload, Gamble at the Saloon, etc. There are even provisions allowed for conducting a Campaign while it is suggested that a Referee be employed for obvious reasons. The Designer has included some of the more well known names of Western characters as well as the better recognized encounters. Another section provides a Bibliography for Western Novel Authors, Western Themed Movies, and Western Non-Fiction books. So Circle the Wagons and Keep them Doggies Rollin'...yee-HAAAAA...*ker-RAACK*...Rawhide!
categories: Adventure, American Indian Wars, American West, Fighting, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Paper-and-Pencil, Role Playing, Simulation, Team-Based Game

name: Intrepid Journey: Game 1 – Survival in the 20th Century
description:
This is a game designed to ensure that players have knowledge about the facts necessary for survival in the 20th century. Questions are very technical, such as "Is a BC dry chemical extinguisher effective on a Class A Fire" or "People may be asphyxiated by volcanic ash (T/F)?"

Play works by rolling a dice and moving around a circular track, asking questions at particular points, with correct answers moving you forward. One must also gather supply points, which can supplement the roll of the die.

The game appears to be out of print, and I cannot find any web references. The rule/question book is 100 pages long. I can take a digital photo of the game if you wish.

name: Forte Trivia Cards Volume II
description: This is the 2nd expansion set of the Forte Trivia cards. It contains a playing guide, one six-colored guide, and 363 cards with 2,178 questions and answers in the categories Whodunit?, Headline News, Westerns, Rock 'n' Roll, Fairy Tales and Mother Goose, and Fair Play. The set is designed to work with "other trivia games".

name: Energy Crisis Game
description:
From the Introduction:"The Energy Crisis Game is an instructive introduction to the complexities of energy management. Get involved in the challenge of planning our nation's energy reserves".

The Game Equipment consists of the following: a mounted Gameboard; a tri-folded Rules sheet; 1-(6)-sided DIE; 60-Ration Cards; 1-Coupon Disbursement Packet; 6-Various COLOR Ration Coupon Cards; 20-Barter Certificates; & $2,140 in various denominations ($10s,$50s,&$100s).

The OBJECT of the Game is to Collect(through buying, selling, bartering, or auctioning), one of EACH of the SAME Color Ration Coupons which are portrayed upon their COLOR Ration Coupon Card. There are various spaces on the gameboard which indicate when a Player can: Collect an amount of Money; Sell, Buy, or Choose a Ration Coupon for some amount of money, BARTER with some other eligible Player, Collect another BARTER Certificate, and on the Supply & Demand spaces-an AUCTION will take place with the Player landing there acting as Auctioneer. There are 2 LARGE Sections of the gameboard designated the "Energy Market Place" and "Coupon Disbursement Center" with a "canceled Ration Coupons" place for when there are less than (6)-Players participating. On each of the COLOR Ration Coupons Cards, there are (3)Sections denoting INDUSTRY, CONSUMER, & GOVERNMENT requirements.
To Start the Game, each Player chooses a Color Pawn and a COLOR Ration Coupon Card, which DOES NOT have to BE of the SAME Color as their PAWN, and then picks one of the (4) corners of the BOARD to begin from. The Players are NOT allowed to perform any action depicted in the CORNER space they begin IN.
Before starting the Game, MIX & place ALL 60 Ration Coupons within the Packet. Then PICK someone to be the Treasurer and then 3 Ration Coupons are picked from the Packet and placed FACE-UP in the Energy Market Section of the gameboard. The Players are EACH given $200 and starting with the Treasurer(banker), randomly pick (5) Ration Coupons from the Packet, placing ANY identically corresponding ones on his OWN Ration Coupon Card. This is performed until EACH Player is left with (5) Ration Coupons in their hand.

Then the DIE is rolled by EACH Player with the HIGHEST Rolling Player going first, RE-Rolling the DIE and MOVING in a clockwise direction from where they Started, & then performing any Action as dictated by the space they've landed on. This is performed on every TURN so the ORDER in which Players MOVE and CONDUCT any ACTIONS can be different each TURN. When a Player Lands on the Supply & Demand space, they MUST then Auction ALL (3)Ration Coupons one at a time, in the "Energy Market Place" and can even participate in the Auction, then the next Player can take their Turn. Once the Auctions are completed, then the "Energy Market Place" is replenished with (3)MORE Ration Coupons picked randomly from the Packet. When a Player lands on a Barter space, he is considered to be the "Head Broker" for any Barter offers. Bartering can only be conducted between the "Head Broker" and another Player as long as THAT Player has a Barter Certificate and once concluded, then a Barter Certificate is given up by the BARTERING Player but NOT the "Head Broker", and placed back with the "Bank". The "Head Broker" can listen to ALL eligible offers and even REFUSE them if they are insufficient to his desires. There are further detailed RULES for Auctioning and Bartering contained in the rather concise RULES sheet.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Commodity Speculation, Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Bumper to Bumper: Real Life Stock Car Racing
description:
As in all automobile racing, to be successful you must combine skill, strategy, and luck to reach victory lane. Bumper to Bumper Race Game is designed to bring all of these aspects into your home. It places all of the decisions made and gambles faced by the drivers and their pit crews into your hands.

Experience the thrill of a multi-car draft, take the gambles of a timely pit stop, and be prepared to take immediate action to avoid the sudden danger of unexpected trouble on the track.

So drivers, strap in, start your engines, and get ready to play Bumper to Bumper Race Game!

name: Bingolino
description:
A 4x4 version of Bingo in a metal box with art by Ulrike Fischer.

Goal
Being the first to cross out a vertical, horizontal or diagonal row of four numbers twice.

Game play
Each player gets a sheet from the notepad. It shows a 4 x 4 grid, into which each player writes the numbers 1 to 16 in a distribution of their choice.
Players then take turns randomly drawing a chip (also numbered 1 to 16) out of the bag. They say the number and everyone crosses out that number on their sheet. This is repeated until a player has crossed out a vertical, horizontal or diagonal row of four numbers. This player gets to stamp a crown on their sheet and a new round starts.
The first player to collect two crowns wins the game.

name: Wörterspaß
description:
The ideal party game for children or the whole family.
It can even be played in twos.

It is a matter "literally" of guessing hidden words of a type which the player has called before.

Using imagination, deduction and some luck a player can find the right word quicker than all others.

name: Tactilo
description: An educational game where the players use their sense of touch to identify the objects on their own personal game card. Players reach into a bag filled with small wooden objects and try to retrieve one of their pieces without looking into the bag.

name: Blarney
description: Object of the game is to get the most scoring chips by convincing other players that your invented definition of an obscure word is the real definition.
publishers: Entertainment Production House, Inc., Mattel, Inc.

name: The Hockey Game
description: All hockey trivia game.

name: All-in-the-Cards Football
description: ALL-IN-THE-CARDS-FOOTBALL is a 15 to 20 minute playing card game that has all the exciting, unbelievable plays that occur in real football, such as: Up to "4" fumbles in one play. Return Interceptions or fumbles from "1" to "-109" yards for a touchdown. Block a kick, return it, and fumble it back over to the kicking team! It is great that all this excitement can be found in a game that can be played almost anywhere , by yourself or with a friend. Since it only takes a short time to play, you can get a few friends together and play a whole season, and you don't even have to play it during football season! How to play? The cards are shuffled by the offensive player after each change of possession. Then the deck of cards is cut by the defensive player. At this point, the offensive player begins by turning every third card to determine the outcome of each play. Strategy: The offensive player must decide on when to punt, kick a field goal, go for a first down or call a time out when needed. Everyone wins with this game, because the end result is ALL-IN-THE-CARDS.
publishers: All-In-The-Cards Football, Inc., The Perfect Game Company

name: Murder à la carte: Brewing Trouble
description:
Hey beer lovers! It's the Rocky Mountain High Beer Festival in Denver, Colorado and you're here for a good time - not a long time. You and your friends have arrived for a weekend of fun, food and beer, but the 'suds' stop flowing when local micro-brewing entrepreneur, Harry Hopps, is found murdered.

The Suspects

Brandy Barleywine - Harry Hopp's partner in Crystal Springs Brewery and his devastatingly beautiful fiancée. Their explosive love-work relationship caused more than a few headaches for the now-deceased master of brew.

Hugh Guzzle - A Canadian beer expert, eh! Hugh, an official Beer Festival judge, has spent the past several years traveling the world in a quest to find a perfect beer. In his day job, Hugh negotiates foreign beer distribution rights for micro-breweries in many different countries.

Lonnie Lager - The drop-dead gorgeous Public Relations Director for Crystal Springs Brewery, Lonnie is a past World Cup ski champion. She is perfect for the job of promoting beer - she has a bubbly personality, pale blond hair and a dry sense of humor.

Bud Belcher - Owner of the upstart Belcher Beer Company, Bud has created a revolutionary new kind of beer. He plans to take the world by storm with his unique 'Millennium Beer' and is looking for investors willing to take a shot at the brass ring.

Sabrina Hartles - The wicked witch of tabloid TV, Sabrina hosts her own television talk show. She has a talent for 'murdering' her guests' reputations on-air. Coincidentally, She is Harry Hopps' ex with a big score to settle.

'Skunky' Brewster - A pioneer in the micro-brewing industry. Skunky, is now retired and 'fermenting' in Florida, as he likes to say. Skunky is attending the Beer Festival to receive a Lifetime Achievement Award and to settle a few old grudges.

Extra Guests Include: (Non-Suspects)

Porter Stout - The local mayor and a man who knows a thing or two about beer-drinking. Porter has worked hard to get national publicity for the festival and will stop at nothing to ensure its success. A pompous politician, he likes to work the crowd at every opportunity. Good hand-shaker.

Heidi Stein - A special guest from Munich, Germany, Heidi is at the Beer Festival to promote the upcoming Octoberfest celebrations in her country. A past polka champion, Heidi is here for a good time, not a long time.

name: Gummi Wars
description:
From the publisher's web site...

Gummi Wars is the new micro-miniatures game that uses candy as miniature figures. All the thrills of fast-paced miniatures combat, with the added bonus that you can eat your dead. What could be better?

name: Blow Me Out of the Sky
description:
From the publisher's web site...

"Funny yes, but this addictive micro-miniatures game will have you screaming for more. Man-to-man modern fighter combat using models, die-cast and plastic toys comes to life in this in-depth strategy game. Everything from basic combat maneuvers to varying armaments and payloads are covered in these fast-paced rules."
categories: Aviation / Flight, Humor, Miniatures, Modern Warfare, Wargame

name: Starship War P.I.G.s
description:
From the publisher's web site...

"Vicious, gigantic bugs want our candy bars and they're willing to invade Earth to get them! The arsenal of the entire planet has turned out to repel them... too bad it's the 1950s and that arsenal doesn't amount to much. Starship War PIGs pits plastic Bugs against plastic Infantry Guys in a titanic miniatures struggle for the mastery of Earth. "

name: Rocky
description: The premise behind the game is matching one boxer and his Action Cards versus the other boxer and his Action Cards. Within each round of boxing each player will FLIP over 8 cards, one at a time, at the same time. Upon flipping each card both players should state the boxing move and the point total out loud. The higher number indicates which boxer wins the exchange. Each time a boxer wins an Exchange he gets closer to gaining a knockdown and closer to winning the round. To signify the winner of an exchange, advance the pawn one notch along the championship belt towards your opponent's KO area.
categories: Fighting, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Sports

name: Tough Luck
description:
Tough Luck is similar to Tripoley (aka Michigan Rummy) but with trick-taking instead of set collection. Each player antes on the 8 money card spots on the game mat plus the Bonus Pot. Players who win cards in a trick that match the spots on the mat get to collect the chips on that spot UNLESS that trick also contains a Tough Luck deuce. In that case, the chips stay on the mat until the next round when that card will be worth even more chips. The Bonus Pot goes to the player who takes the most tricks in a round UNLESS there is a tie in which case the bonus pot is carried over into the next round too.

For 2 to 6 players Ages 8 and up.

name: Rattler
description:
In this Roll and Move game, players try to be the first to reach the gold mine at the top of the mountain. However, as they progress, prospectors can be randomly sent back down by the Rattler! mechanical device.

From the back of the box:

It's a thrilling journey to the Lost Gold Mine in this suspense-filled game. Move your prospector up the mountain trail, but beware. There's a rattler inside the mountain, and when you hear the hiss, you'll know he's ready to strike. If the rattler strikes through the door, you'll have to go back to start. The first player to get his prospector to the Lost Gold Mine at the top of the mountain wins.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Big Bird's Nesticks
description: A sort of Pick a stick action game. Big Bird is placed on a nest of sticks -- a bowl with sticks jutting up from it, keeping the Big Bird figure upright. The object is to pull the sticks out of the nest without making Big Bird fall. The player who makes Big Bird fall is out, and the other players win, or set up the game again, and play until all players but one have been eliminated.
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Pictionary: Austin Powers
description: This party game is a bit of all right. You'll be surprised at how many words you can draw while playing Pictionary the Austin Powers edition. This new game of quick draw features five new categories ranging from Austin Powers Mojo to Evil Empire and Superspy Stuff.
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Party Game, Spies/Secret Agents

name: One Road too Far: Operation Lam Son, 1971
description: This game covers Operation Lam Som, the 1971 offensive into Laos intended to cut the Ho Chi Minh trail. Units are companies and batallions; the two small maps have hexes representing about 850 yards of territory. This desktop-published game requires one to assemble the counters prior to play.

name: A Cold Day In Hell
description:
It's the day nobody thought would come, especially the Devil. Temperatures in Hell have taken a real nose-dive. For the first time ever government offices in Hell have turned off the air conditioning.

It's downright COLD!

While everybody is loving this break from the eternal heat, there is one problem: the Devil can't find his winter coat. He swears he put it in his closet after his last ski vacation in the Alps. But, it's been an eternity since then, and how often does he really need his winter coat in hell anyway?

Your task is to find the Devil's winter coat before he gets his panties in a bunch.

(This is an e-game; you can purchase it for download, and print it out.)

name: Fat Chance
description: The object of the game is to lose the lard. Each player starts with 20 unwanted pounds of lard and the goal is to lose them. Players move around the board answering questions in categories such as Calories count, Nutrition matters, Exercise and the body and Largely trivia.
mechanics: Memory, Roll / Spin and Move, Tile Placement

name: Kapture
description: Abstract strategy game with a science-fiction flavor. The goal of the game is to surround opponent's pieces with certain capturing formations. A player wins if he surrounds the same opposing piece three times, if he captures all of the opposing pieces, or if he surrounds more pieces than his opponent does.

name: Meeting Room
description:
The represenatives of 3 Italian game companies Acqui Comics, Mucca games and da Vinci Academy have decided to have run the game convention of all conventions, the "Con-Con." The plans are held in a tiny Meeting Room. Each player is a secretary of the CON-CON (i.e. the CONvention of the CONventios), managing the MEETING ROOM and his goal is to organize qualified and prestigious meetings, gaining points in the process.

Using cards from their hand, the player tries to fill three chairs in the meeting room. Hands are built by drawing face down and face up cards, collecting sets of characteristics which are found on each card in different combinations (game company, favorite game type and job). Completing sets is worth various amounts of points and players earn bonuses for filling up all three chairs with cards from their hand.

The first player to score 30 points wins.

name: Cluedo: After Dinner Mint Edition "Death by Indulgence"
description:
A simplified version classic detective game, but with a chocloate twist. The rules are basically the same, the exception being that mint chocolates are placed in each room at the start of play to entice players to enter the rooms. The first person in each room gets the reward!.

The game comes in a small box, (perfect for picnic hampers) and the playing time and board are reduced by dropping a few of the rooms.

name: 3x3 und eins vorbei
description:
This is a simple game for children starting at the age of 2 or 3, or mentally impaired persons (says the game designer).
It's kind of a simple version of Pachisi with different levels of difficulty, e.g. you don't use a normal dice, but a dice with different colors instead of numbers.

name: GoBots GIANT Card Game
description:
The object of this children's card game is to be the first player to collect ten or more pictures of their GoBot. Each player is trying to collect a different GoBot (either Leader-1, Royal-T, Cy-Kill, or Cop-Tur).

There are 31 oversized cards, and each has four pictures of GoBots. Two different GoBots are represented on each card. For example, a card may have two pictures of Leader-1, and two pictures of Cop-Tur. Or, it could have three pictures of Royal-T, and only one of Cy-Kill. (Cards always have either 2+2 or 3+1 pictures.)

On their turn, a player draws one card from the draw deck or the discard pile. If at least one of the four pictures on that card is of the GoBot that the player is trying to collect, they keep it and play if face up on the table. All of the cards a player collects are placed side by side, in front of him. If the card drawn doesn't pictures the player's GoBot, the player discards it face down.

There are also five Zap Cards. When a player draws a zap card, he places it on top of (covering, or "zapping") any four pictures on an opponent's cards, either over one whole card, or overlapping it to cover one half of two different cards.

The winner is the player who is the first to collect ten pictures of their GoBot.
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Mayhem: Wasteland Warriors
description:
From the designer: "Set in the apocalyptic near future MAYHEM Wasteland Warriors is man to man combat at it's finest. Travel the desert wastelands of the US southwest while you lead a band of survivors. Perfect for modern combat as well Wasteland Warriors has a truly unique combat system. Linked by a simple "encounter" system all battles can be fought as a campaign. Playable with any already based figures. Perfect for playing alone or with a group of friends..."

Scifi desert combat with miniatures. Can be played solo or with lots of players.
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Variable Player Powers

name: Mayhem: Muskets and Mohawks
description:
From the designer: "Covering both the French & Indian War and the American War of Independence MAYHEM: Muskets & Mohawks is both a skirmish combat game and campaign system. Whether you're on a mission with a group of Roger's Rangers or leading the charge with the 1st Maryland, MAYHEM - Muskets & Mohawks allows you do it in a realistic way. Linked by a simple "encounter" system all battles can be fought as a campaign. Playable with any already based figures. Perfect for playing alone or with a group of friends. A great way to get into a new period for a low investment in time and money..."

Skirmish in colonial times with miniatures.
categories: Age of Reason, American Indian Wars, American Revolutionary War, Fighting, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Dice Rolling, Modular Board

name: Tri Tac Toe
description:
Tri Tac Toe is yet another version of 3-D tic-tac-toe, featuring a 3x3x3 grid in clear plastic.

Actually, two games are provided - Tri Tac Toe itself is about as you would expect, with the sole difference from the standard game being that the winner is the player who creates the most rows of 3.

The other game is called 3-D Target Checkers, and is basically Chinese Checkers, except that there is no jumping.

Note that the "gametime" that produced this game is not the same one that produced Spellmaker, Star Fighter, etc. - that one was a division of Heritage.
publishers: Gametime, Inc., Hoi Polloi Inc., Reiss Games

name: AM/FM Music Trivia
description: This is an unofficial card set to be used with a trivial pursuit game.
publishers: PDQ Software Inc, Prism Leisure Corporation PLC, Time Life

name: 21 Letters
description: 7 cards are drawn from a deck of 54 cards (with three letters printed on the cards) and placed face up on the table. Players must create words using as many of the letters as possible in 2 minutes. Bonus points are awarded for longer words and for using all 21 letters. Winner is the first one to an agreed point total.

name: The Artifact
description:
Taken from the publisher's website:

The Artifact takes us in a fantasy world far away, where humans, magical and evil creatures can be easily found walking around, just as in any Tolkien-inspired game. Players take up the role of one of these heroes (a Human, a Dwarf, an Elf and a Hobbit, indeed) and must recover their weapon, which is proved to be the only mean to destroy a powerful Artifact that is trying to put under its control the whole world. The path to the Mountain of Fate, the place where the Artifact is giving out its will, is full of dangerous creatures such as Trolls, Orcs and the mighty Black Knight. During his turn, the player rolls two different colored six-sided dice, thus determining both his hero movement and which of the evil character will be moved by the player sitting to his right. You got it: players are trying both to win advantage for their heroes and to stop the other players' ones at the same time. And if it's not your lucky day, you may even change the outcome you have rolled, but are you ready to pay its price, giving your opponents a free move? The game gets even more interesting because each evil character has its own special ability, and the map represents different types of terrain: each hero has a favored type of terrain (e.g. woods for the Elf) where he can peacefully rest and plan his next moves. Last but not least, there is also the possibility of casting a powerful spell and then bend evil characters' wills to yours...

This game was available in the free web magazine GiocAreA OnLine (former partner of daVinci Editrice) as a promotional tool.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Chifoumi
description: A hybrid of rock-paper-scissors and checkers in which players move pieces of four kinds over a cross-shaped board.

name: Shrink
description:
Every Player (Patient) get 4 Symptom Cards that show their Brain disease.
On the Symptom Cards is a List of Treatments that you must take step by step from the Top to the Bottom to heal the disease.
To heal you must visit some Places in turn (First the Doctor,Then the Drugstore, ect...)and pay there Money for the Treatment.If more than one Card need the same Treatment at the same Time, you must only pay once for all same Treatments. That save Time and Money.
To win the Game you must Cure all 4 Diseases.

In the Game box:
1 Gameboard
1 Bottle with Clips (To mark the last Treatment of Symptom Card you take.)
33 Symptom Cards
54 Brainstorm Cards (17 Good,17 Bad)
A lot of Game money

name: Talk Dirty to Me
description: The object of the game is to score the LEAST amount of points by using the most words in your hand of cards to fill in the blanks in various stories. A deck of 98 cards (printed in black and red) is shuffled and each player is dealt five cards. The current player or storyteller begins to read a story from the story book and stops at the first blank. The storyteller then flashes the bookmark to let the player know what color card can be used to fill in the blank as indicted in the story book. If the player has an appropriate word card of the right color, the player reads the card aloud and discards the card. If the player is unable to play an appropriate card, they must draw the next card from the deck. That card must be played if possible. If the card cannot be played, play passes to the next player to attempt to fill the blank. Each of the word cards is worth from five to fifteen points. At the end of each story, players add the cards remaining in their hand and scores are recorded. A full game consists of twelve stories. The player with the lowest score after the last story wins.

name: Quadrivium
description:
Spanish generic board game. The game comes with an amount of generic elements likes color tokens, color pawns, normal dice, colour dice... The more special element is the board.

Quadrivium is really a meta-game: a game that allows to play and create different games by using the generic components.

In the basic rules there are 4 games:

1. "El Último Gana" (The last wins), a quick game of elimination.
2. "Quarchís" (a word-play with Parchís [Ludo in Spanish]and the name of the game Quadrivium), a variant of Ludo for 4 players.
3. "El Color de las Palabras" (The color of Words), a crosswords game.
4. "El Caserón de los Espectros" (The House of the Ghosts), an adventure game of strategy and mystery.

In the publisher's website there are four more games: http://www.quiz.es/quiz1/produc/opquad2.htm

name: Drei gewinnt
description:
Players take turns adding their pieces to the stand. Whoever gets three of their color in a row wins.

Contents:
1 cup
18 red pieces
18 ecru pieces
10 black pieces

name: Beach Maze
description:
Beach Maze comes in a canvas bag. The roll-up board has to be set up to play: stretch the canvas board over the provided sticks and legs, and it makes a little table that not only stands up well on the beach, it actually requires sand to stand up well as it's a little wobbly on its own... The pieces are all wooden, and there are no cards to lose or get wet - it really does play well at the beach. (You can just lay the canvas board flat on your gaming table if not at the beach.)

Each player has four baby turtles, just hatched, which must get to the sea. These start on your edge of the board, on little cracked-egg spaces. First player to get all four turtles off the board wins. (The sea is represented by a space at the center of the board, a little disconcerting ...) Each turn you roll one die and move any one turtle the number showing, with no backtracking.

Other wooden pieces on the board are dunes. You cannot cross a dune: you have to land on one exactly. In so doing, you remove it from the board and must place it on some other space. Your best option, of course, is somewhere that blocks your opponent ...

Landing on an opponent's turtle sends it back to a start space.

Two of the dune pieces have crabs on the back, which can be used in an optional rule. (Crabs are the enemies of newly hatched baby turtles ...)

name: Snoop
description: A deck of cards marked one to eleven are shuffled and five are dealt to each player. On their turn, players lay down any pairs in their hand in front of them. Current players may ask the player to their left for a specific card, but does not have to be a card that they have to form a pair. If the player being asked for a card claims not to have that card, the current player rolls the die. If the die is blank, the current players turn is over. If a red dot is rolled, the current player may use the Snooper to examine the back of the second players cards. If the card asked for is in the second players hand, he must give it to the current player. The second player is also penalized a pair of cards already played for being caught bluffing. If the player caught bluffing does not have a pair to give, the current player may draw a card from the second players hand. The game is over when all of the cards have been laid out face up in pairs on the table and no players have cards in their hands. The player with the greatest number of pairs is the winner.

name: Galaxia
description:
From the box: "You hang stars and planets on the rotating wheel. When they fall off they are transformed into valuable shooting stars. But watch out; It's not up to you if you're lucky or not! You have to get instructions and then hang stars and planets on the wheel. Whatever falls off is gathered up by the player who gave you the instructions. So you have to demonstrate skill and care so that the other players won't collect too many points in the form of shooting stars. On the other hand, you should give such instructions which result in as many stars as possible falling off...
For those who prefer to harvest shooting stars trying their own luck and skill there is an additional game variant.
A sky-borne game of skill for the whole family.

Contents: 1 star wheel, 12 big stars, 12 small stars, 16 planets."

name: Beachcomber
description:
From the rules:

INTRODUCTION: BEACHCOMBER was created by two world sailors. After rounding Cape Hatteras in a 60' schooner, they found refuge from the storm in Silver Lake Harbor on Orcacoke Island. During their stay on Ocracoke they found the Outer Banks life-style so unique that they were inspired to capture that feeling, and the game of Beachcomber came to life.

BASIC SUMMARY: This is a card game in the vein of Mille Bornes. One's goal is to collect the most shells (similar to mileage cards). The quantity of shells one can pick up is based on the mode of transportation (food, bike, 4x4), and there are various problems that can slow you down (soft sand, no reservation, hot sand). You must be on vacation to collect shells (similar to the Go card), and there are things that can frustrate the vacation (hotel bill, food bill, beach gear bill, and gas bill); bills can be addressed with money or "super solutions."

name: Morená
description:
Morena is a cooperative story telling activity. There are two decks of cards. One deck has 88 pictures that depict scenes of tribal life in the Brazilian jungle, the other comprises 22 track cards that can be used as transitions between the scenes of the former deck.

As a player draws and plays a card, he or she tells a story about the card, using the scene depicted as an inspiration. As more cards are drawn, the players build up a grand tale, using their descriptions of the scenes played as components. Players can chose not to pass or not to play the cards they have drawn. As the activity is purely cooperative, no one can interrupt or contradict each other's contribution to the tale that is being spun.

name: Klüngel & Millionen
description:
A game about a special behavior in Cologne (and maybe other countries?) called "Klüngel". If You help me, I will help You! The aim is, to enter certain clubs, parties, pressure groups and use the attained position to get influence, prestige and reputation.

This is a dice game where you are able to negotiate about all rules. And there are action cards in it.
categories: Comic Book / Strip, Dice, Humor, Negotiation, Political

name: Robbi Robbe
description:
A dexterity game in which players have to balance a tower of cards and wooden chips on a wooden seal figure.

Game play
Players have to stack cards and chips on the back of Robbi, a wooden seal figure. The colour of the ball depicted on the top card on Robbi's back determines which player is next. A joker card lets the current player decide who has to go next. The active player has to put one of his/her chips on the card, turn over the next card and place the card on the chip. If he/she successfully completes the turn, he/she gets the "Theo, the zookeeper" pawn. When the stack of cards and pawns collapses, the player who currently has the Theo pawn (i.e. the last player to have added a chip and card without collapsing the stack) gets a fish card.

The game ends when a player has collected three fish cards. That player wins the game.
categories: Action / Dexterity, Animals, Card Game, Children's Game

name: 6 kleine Spiele
description: This is a little game collection. 6 games in a little box. 3 Dice games - racing, one memory game, one skill game and one tactical game.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Memory, Pattern Building, Race

name: Into the Dragon's Cave
description:
A series of six different games, all with the same gameplay:

Into the Dragon's Cave (fantasy);
Into the Deserted Chapel (horror);
Into the Domain of Capella (science fiction);
Into the Dark Continent (Victorian adventure);
Into the Dear Caress (romance);
Into the Dream Centre (surrealism).

Each of them come in a ziplock bag with A4 sheets of cardstock. You have to cut out the 200 cards to create the game. The rules take up half a single sheet of the cardstock.

Before beginning, shuffle the cards and then choose the size of the deck used in the game. All 200 cards would make for a very long game and is not recommended except for masochists. The shortest variant is simply to use the initial six cards dealt you and no more. They also give estimated playing times for 50 and 100 cards.

Game play is reminiscent of Once Upon a Time. There are no "Happy Ever After" cards, however: you choose a card from your initial hand to be your ending card. The cards have phrases or single words on them, largely relevant to the individual genre. On your turn, you play a single card, weave it into the story, and then draw a card from the draw pile. Play then passes to the next player, who does the same. Players may boo and heckle your input, in which case you have to do it over. This game is definitely concerned more with the quality of story than competition.

In fact, victory conditions are very understated.
