categories: Card Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Print & Play, Science Fiction

name: Word for Word Reading Rods
description:
From Discovery Toys:

"In a fast-paced race against the clock, build as many words as you can and strengthen phonics and spelling skills. Players at different reading levels can play at the same time using specified combinations of colored rods. Or practice with basic word families, rhyming words and blended sounds at your own pace with the included activity book (used in schools to teach reading). Especially helpful for kinesthetic and visual learners."

name: Road Rally
description:
One in a series of sixteen Flipsiders games designed to resemble pastel colored audio cassettes. The game contained a metal gameboard that would flip out with the snap of the wrist. A storage compartment at the top of the game would hold the magnetic pawns. A spring-loaded switch would spin the wheels of the cassette to generate random numbers and events during play. The game would hang from a blister pack on display at the store.

The spinners determine how far one may move during one’s turn. The players will compete in three races and the first to complete all three races is the winner.

name: Erfenis
description: Old Lord Humbug is rich. More than 600 years of thriftiness and savings in the family has left the Lord with considerable property, stocks, many family heirlooms and 100 million English pounds that will be distributed to the family members when the Lord dies. However, all of the heirs have already waited a very long time: the old Lord refuses to die! He is already 86 and could live another 100 years! The possible heirs are: the sparing sister Lady Scrape Humbug, the poor old friend of the family Sir Humpty, Trickenham the butler, Miss Fuzzy the careless daughter, Spoiler Humbug the prodigal son, and Vanity the ambitious mistress. They each try in every way possible to influence the old man, in an effort to win the him over and get the inheritance for themselves. Players in this game take the part of these heirs are.

name: Fußball: Fieber
description:
One soccer star is kidnapped, and the kidnapper has killed people as well. Who hates Soccer enough to do this at the World Cup?

All players (5 male, 6 female (+ 1 m/f)) should act out their roles to solve the mystery, because one of the guests is the murderer

name: Proverbial Wisdom Junior
description: This is a simplified version of Proverbial Wisdom. There are three types of challenges for players: try to sketching, acting or define a saying. Comes with a spinner, card tray with sketch cards, picture cards and definition cards, clue hider, timer and sketch board. The first team to collect three of each card type wins.
categories: Children's Game, Party Game, Trivia, Word Game

name: Viking Waves
description:
Viking Waves takes place in the areas raided and conquered by the Norwegian and Danish Vikings during the early Viking Age. It's a game primarily for two players, though limited solitaire play is also possible. The various Viking chieftains rarely fought each other directly, so players compete indirectly.

The game is divided into three phases, each of which involves dozens of raids/attacks and which can be played as a separate game (or all three can be played sequentially as a campaign). In Phase 1, which lasts from 792 until around 834, each raid involves a few ships and lasts only a few days. In Phase 2, from around 834 to around 850–864, raids are larger. In Phase 3, from around 850–864 until 879, the goal is conquering land with armies and creating permanent settlements.

In the standard game, each player represents an ever-changing group of Norwegian and Danish chieftains. Optional rules allow for the historical division of territory between Norwegian and Danish groups, allow for limited combat between the two players, and provide for solitaire play.

One twelve-page rulebook
Two 8.5" x 11" maps
One Player Display
342 counters
categories: Medieval, Print & Play, Territory Building, Wargame

name: The Bird-Table Game
description:
"Find out how to identify the birds in YOUR garden!"

In this game, players move around the board collecting points by correctly identifying and answering questions about wild birds that might be found in British gardens. Although prior knowledge helps, it's not essential: the game is designed to help players develop their bird-related expertise.

name: Mergers & Acquisitions: The Hostile Takeover Game
description:
In this game, you become a business owner attempting to increase your company's profits through hostile takeovers of other companies. You have investment money of 1.2 billion dollars to finance your coming mergers and acquisitions.

Your goal is to buy other companies at a relatively low price compared to their value. If you control that company, your company's profits will increase as well.

The basics of the game:

There is one more business than there are the number of players, each with different company values. Players each have 14 chips with investment values printed on them (4 X 5, 3 X 10, 3 X 50, 1 X 100, 1 X 200, 1 X 300, 1 X 400). They (usually) secretly place these one at a time near a business they wish to invest in. The 2nd, 5th, and some later investments made in each company are made publicly (everyone sees the investment amount).

Players gain control of a company by having more invested in the company at the end of the game than any of the other players (and get more points for having more than all the other players combined). The tricky part being that a player will almost always need to have control of 2 or more business to win, but there's not enough businesses to be able to do so easily, so each player *will* have to out-invest another player, which involves bluffing them as to where your high-value investment chips are.

Each player also chooses an 'investment strategy' card at the beginning of the game, and plays it at some point during the game, changing things like making the value of a company halved, or giving them extra shares in a company, etc.

name: Disqualified!
description:
Disqualified! is the new driving board game from Tucker Enterprises which uses movement around the board is not determined by the throw of a dice, but as a result of the speed you choose to drive, combined with the effect of various hazards and the ever present possibility of being stopped by a Police car.

You are racing against your opponents to be the first to complete a journey of 500 miles. The player driving the Police car however has a different objective: To win he/she must endorse everyone else's license with 12 penalty points and Disqualify them from the game.

name: Lukas: oder wie man eine Schleife bindet
description:
Description from Spielbox:

Dirk Hanneforth invented this teaching game for the very young. Each child gets a colored shoe as well as a matching shoelace. The shoe has holes which have colored edges. Now, the color die comes into play. The first player tries his luck: If the die shows his own color, then he gets to thread his shoelace into one of the next two free holes in his shoe. If it’s a different color, then he has to look carefully: If red was rolled and a free hole is also red, then he gets to thread the lace. If, however, none of the next holes are red, then he gets to give away the color by choosing an opponent who needs the color and can use it to continue threading his lace. As soon as a child has succeeded in completely threading his shoelace, he wins the game. If he can then also tie a knot, he’s laughing. The others can practice via the illustrated instructions.

Ages 4 and up. Artwork: Kerstin Völker

name: Split
description: Each of the two players chooses a color from among those on the perimeter of the board shown, and each places one of his tokens (such as black and white Go stones) onto each of the two spaces of his color. Then they alternately place their tokens into vacant spaces, trying to form a connected path between their original perimeter spaces.

name: Aleph Bet Adventure
description:
From the Publisher:

Get ready for an exciting adventure! You are going to be whisked off to an animal safari park filled with all your favorite animals and characters. Starting with the first Hebrew letter Aleph and all the way to the last letter Tov, you'll find a friendly group who is ready to help you learn the Hebrew alphabet. This fun and colorful board game provides early exposure to the Hebrew alphabet, and builds important beginning reading skills such as letter recognition, initial sounds, and more. No reading required. Perfect for school or home! For 2-4 players ages 3 and up.

name: Moneywise Kids
description:
from the publisher:

Game Concept: Practice making change while players earn a $100 bill. Then learn to budget money while spending it on life’s necessities, such as housing, food, clothing, etc.

Special Features: Two simple, fast-paced games to improve valuable math skills that kids will use all their lives. Includes facsimiles of real U.S. money. Tips are featured that parents and teachers can use to connect Moneywise Kids play with the real world.

name: Quick Pix Animals
description:
From the publisher

Each game features a set of problem and answer cards. Players need to be the first to match the correct answer card to the problem card that is turned over. To win, you must think quickly, match faster and capture as many card pairs as possible.

Quick Pix Animals -- Which group an animal belongs to (reptile, bird, crustacean, etc.)

name: The Game of Wisdom
description:
The basis of the game is to convince a JUDGE and collect LAURELS. You roll the die, move one of your tokens and draw a card corresponding to the color you landed on. The JUDGE gives 15 seconds (timer not included) for anyone else who would like THE RIGHT TO SPEAK to indicate they would like to answer. After the time has elapsed the JUDGE rereads the question back to the original player, the payer has 30 seconds to answer and reason (Yes/No is not sufficient). There is CRITERIA to determine if the answer is acceptable. The JUDGE, regardless of if the answer is to their taste, awards a LAUREL to any answer that meets criteria. A player may CHALLENGE a ruling and risk losing two LAURELS. Anyone else who has asked for THE RIGHT TO SPEAK may provide their answer. If they REPEAT what the first answer was, they lose a LAUREL. If they also provide a satisfactory answer, they receive a LAUREL. After a player has answered one of each coloured card and has 12 LAURELS they may predict even or odd on their turn and finish PHASE 1

For PHASE 2

As the player CLIMBS THE LADDER OF WISDOM in phase two, they must always contribute an answer on another players turn by using the RIGHT TO SPEAK TOKEN. As well, on their turn they must Guess EVEN/ODD before rolling. Being unable to answer or failing to contribute costs five LAURELS or go down a rung. Once at the top there is a final guess of EVEN / ODD to be declared THE GREAT THINKER.
categories: Math, Negotiation, Party Game, Puzzle, Word Game

name: Politiskt korrekt?
description: Politiskt korrekt? is a Swedish game produced by the market liberal think tank Timbro. It is a light hearted trivia card game highlighting economic and political facts combined with a bit of humor.

name: Crossfire
description:
Inspired by Sid Sackson's classic abstract Focus, Crossfire is a stacking game played on a hexagonal grid.

Piece stacks have a maximum size dependent on how many neighboring hexes it has. Excess pieces in a stack are removed from the bottom by the stack's controller and either returned to the stack controller's reserve to return to the board later, or else are captured and removed from the game.

A move consists of a player moving either a stack he controls, or pieces from the top of a stack he controls, and then moves those pieces in a straight line a number of spaces up to the number of pieces being moved. Alternatively, a player may introduce a piece from his reserve onto any space on the board.

The game is won when he forces his opponent into a position where his opponent cannot make a move.

name: Terran
description:
Terran was produced in Perth, Western Australia.
It is basically an 8 x 8 chess style board with pieces moving around on the vertices's instead of in the squares. There is an interesting center vertex which allows the bishop type pieces to change from one set of diagonals to the other. There are five different types of pieces all with differing moves of 1 or 2 spaces (like restricted chess pieces). The pieces are bright yellow and red plastic. The aim of the game is to capture the opposition command center piece.

name: Frontline General
description:
The Frontline General 'Land, Air, & Sea Tabletop Simulation' is an Operational and Tactical Level WWII Consim. The system covers Land, Air, and Sea wargaming mostly at the Operational level with a tactical 'feel'. The board wargame may be used to 'drive' more detailed tabletop miniatures battles for decisive engagements. Miniatures combat expands on the level of detail and is entirely optional.

Frontline General: Italian Campaign expands on the published introductory game, Frontline General: Italian Campaign Introduction, by adding a large size map of Southern Italy (See the Image Gallery), more Units, an additional country (the United Kingdom), and five historical scenarios covering action from Salerno to the Gustav Line.

The game will be available as a standalone game or as an upgrade to the Frontline General: Italian Campaign Introduction.

The introductory version linked above is the first release in the series and is currently available as a production version and a free Print & Play version.

Collins Epic Wargames provides rules support via website forums and e-mail and also publishes a Newsletter called Frontline General News with in-depth articles, examples, and previews of upcoming products. All back issues of FG News are available online.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Secret Unit Deployment

name: Battle-Axe: Wargames Rules for Medieval Skirmishes
description:
Wargame for Medieval Skirmishes

A painted knight on a hex base take on a man at arms while a couple of archers fling arrows at him. How he swings his sword is factored in the turn and the priority of thrusting before the cut or swings will dictates who will win.

28 pages with some hex pattern "board", charts for orders and abilities and a pull out Summary Sheet help the gameplay.

One small Erratum sheet:

Please note that on the summary sheet 2 for firing and melee, the Melee Procedure contains a typing error:
Line 4 should read "For each hit throw 3 D6 & add attacker's AA."

name: Regimental Chess
description:
(From the Introduction in the rules.)
Regimental Chess is ... a battle by a division of chess pieces on a (board) three times larger than traditional chess.

Each side has 14 infantrymen (pawns), 4 bishops, 4 knights, 4 rooks, 2 queens, and a king. Pieces may move individually or in battalions. A battalion is the group of each piece type, e.g. 4 bishops are a battalion. Battalion movement is all pieces making the same move (e.g., three diagonally northwest). It's like station keeping in naval fleet movement. Or battalions can move in a chain, each advancing forward to take the place of the other, like marching forward. All pieces have to spaced apart equally for chain movement.

It was a commercially available game. The map provided was a roll up chess board. The pieces were of good quality plastic in the traditional Staunton chess piece style.

name: Legrand
description:
Each player has a set of 20 tiles of different shapes and sizes: 12 x 5-size, 5 x 4-size, 2 x 3-size and 1 x 2-size (88 squares in total). The game is played on a 14x14 board, but five 2x2 spaces are forbidden areas - giving 176 playable spaces.

Each tile has small triangles on all sides. If 2 pieces are laying attached to each other, the triangles form squares on the common sides. These squares are called "towers" and they are important to capture opposing pieces, since they represent the strength of attacking/defending tiles.

Winner of the game is the player who is the first who can lay down all his 20 tiles on the board.

name: Tanbark Trail
description:
Tanbark Trail attempts to simulate the exciting world of Holstein show ring competition. The object of the game is to win ribbons and trophies which at the end of the game are converted to points. The player with the most points wins.

At the start of the game, a set number of cattle are auctioned off to the players. During the game, players may purchase more cattle from the sales barn, sell animals back to the sales barn, or trade or purchase from each other.

There are also random event cards drawn during the game that operate much like "Chance" or "Community Chest" cards in Monopoly.

Players move around a board depicting a fairgrounds, at the center of which is the show ring. Any time a player moves his token into the show ring, a competition begins. At this point players must pay an entry fee for each animal they wish to enter in each show class. First, second, and third-place winners are determined by combining die rolls with stats on that animal's card.

The first three rounds of show competition are considered to be State competitions, and the fourth a National competition. After the fourth round, all award ribbons are converted to points, and the winner is determined.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: The Shepherd's Game
description: The Shepherd's game, or Schäferspiel, is an early roll and move game, unique in that it employs the rolling of two dice. One normal d6, and the other with color designation. The game offers multiple movement options as the color dice designates which pawns are able to move. Money is awarded when farmers land on designated spots while either sheep or dogs are also on specific spaces. Winner is the shepherd with the most money when all sheep are finally herded back into their pasture.

name: Scriptorium
description:
(Description from the publisher:)
You make up words using your letters to a selected theme.
You put them down, or move around those already on the table.
You defend them against other players... you can reject them!
The first player who has no more cards wins the game and... "Rien ne va plus!"

name: The Odyssey of Homer
description:
Colorful comics-style artwork adorns the board for this roll-and-move point-collection game that projects a strong theme of the Odyssey.

Peril and Destiny cards provide variety to the basic 2d6 movement, as well as the occasional "take that" opportunity to penalize another player. If you get too many Peril cards, you return to the beginning of the map, which can be both a blessing and a curse. Destiny and Peril cards often have you performing actions that distract from the goal of the game: to be the player with the most points when the first player reaches the end of the journey, Ithaca. Points are normally gathered by landing on starred spaces.

The first person to reach the end of the journey gets an extra five points, but that's no guarantee of victory!
mechanics: Events, Paper-and-Pencil, Roll / Spin and Move, Take That, Track Movement

name: The Aristocrats
description:
In 2005, Penn Jilette sponsored a contest for the DVD release of his documentary, The Aristocrats. The best submissions of the joke, The Aristocrats, would be included on the DVD.

This game was one of the submissions. It lost.

Now, Insane Game Designer Mike Young has placed it on his website free for download.

The Aristocrats card game plays just like Crazy Eights or Uno, except that you must play two cards on your turn instead of one. The object is to rid yourself of all of your cards before anyone else does the same. You tell the story/joke of The Aristocrats during the course of the game and are encouraged to be as creative, clever and, well, disgusting as possible.

The more players you have, the longer the game will take.

Warning: This game contains graphic descriptions of disgusting and perverted acts both sexual and scatological. It is not intended for children, the easily offended, the general public, or people who can't take a joke.
categories: Card Game, Humor, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Party Game, Print & Play
publishers: (Web published), Interactivities Ink, The Game Crafter, LLC

name: Cricket
description:
Unusual offering from John Sands. Comes with a small Masonite cricket bat, table tennis balls, a rectangular plastic grid and a series of flat cardboard cricket balls, each sporting a particular outcome (3, 6, run out etc.).

The cricket balls are placed in a plastic grid of squares, one in each compartment, by the 'bowler' who then tosses the table tennis ball at the batsman from a pre-agreed distance. The player holding the Masonite bat must attempt to hit the table tennis ball into the plastic grid, preferably landing the ball in a favorable compartment.

name: Pirate's Island
description: A roll and move race game, where you have to avoid the pirates awaiting to ambush. Game mechanics are straight forward, but the colorful board and pieces add a lot to this early 20th century parlor game. Another excuse to say, "Argggh".

name: The World at War
description:
From the website http://web.archive.org/web/20100110052915/http://www.tsoa.be/html/titelblad_uk_world_at_war.html :

The "World at War" is another rules set in our card driven color coded hex based series. Although it was one of our first projects, it has taken us nearly two years to finish, since mechanized warfare is quite different from e.g. colonial or ACW. Our main objective was to write a set of rules that would allow a fast, yet as realistic as possible wargame.

In order to keep the actual number of pages as low as possible, we have opted for a system that may be compared with "Lego". You may have a huge pile of Lego blocks at hand, yet to build a house, you will only use the ones you need. In our system, the "unit cards" stand for the Lego blocks: there is a huge choice of different units for each nation, yet you will only need those you have units for in the game.

The number of COMMAND CARDS is similar to the other games. So far, we have finished the D-Day to Berlin units for Germany and the USA.
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Dice Rolling

name: The Million Dollar Bank Game
description:
Designed primarily as an adult game, The Million Dollar Bank Game enters game players into the real world of banking based on the United States banking system. No prior financial experience is needed to play! the game will give you the insight on how the modern day banking system works and operates.

Goal: The first player to become a million dollar depositor with the bank while having repaid all their loans ... WINS THE GAME.

Package of Contents:

Gameboard
Career Moves (24 playing cards)
Life Fortune (30 playing cards)
Errors or Favors (25 playing cards)
"HOME" (5 cards)
New Account Passbooks (5 types)
Loan Documents (5 types)
Liquid Cash Play Money (7 denominations)
Playing Dice (2)
Piggy Bank Game Markers (4)


OBJECT OF THE GAME: The object is to become a Million Dollar Saver. The first player to acquire One Million Dollars ($1,000,000) in New Account Passbooks while having repaid all their loans, wins the game.

STRATEGY OF THE GAME: Invest your liquid cash (money) into New Account Passbooks which will earn you interest. You will have to decide the advantages and disadvantages of investing in the different New Account Passbooks. Make use of loans to expand your investing options. Be aware that you can acquire liquid cash by entering Loan Row and securing loans (Loan Documents) or you can secure Passbook Loans on your New Account Passbooks (Take advantage of Home Loans; when they sell, you make big money in profits). The first player to acquire a million dollars in New Account Passbooks and pay off all their Loan Documents and Passbook Loans declares him or herself the winner.

name: Shot Tac Toe
description: Played like regular Tic-Tac-Toe with the loser drinking all of the shots on the board. A draw leads to both players drinking their own shots and the game is replayed if possible.

name: 'The Jungle Book' Game
description:
From the introduction found in the rules:

'Mowgli, as you know, must leave the Cave and return to the Man Village, accompanied by some of his jungle friends to see him safely on his way. So they decide to make a "race" of it, to see who can be the first to reach the Man Village.

As you will remember, Kaa the snake and Shere Khan the tiger, try to stop Mowgli and his friends-and there are other interruptions on the way.'

This is a 3-dimensional game set in the 'jungle' of the Walt Disney adaptation of 'The Jungle Book' with stand up trees and bushes.
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Cheskers
description:
This game is a combination of chess and checkers. It was originally published in a chess fanzine [which one?]. It is played on a normal checkerboard. The setup is identical to checkers, except for the rear 4 "checkers". On the back row, in place of the four checkermen each player has two checker kings (moving and capturing as in normal American checkers), one bishop and one cook (Golomb's name for a (3,1)-leaper, more commonly known as a Camel).

When a checker man gets to the back row, it can be promoted into a bishop, cook or checker king. The bishops move and capture precisely as in chess, viz., capturing by replacement. The cooks move and capture like chess knights, except that they move to the opposite corner of a 4x2 rectangle rather than a 3x2 rectangle. Thus both bishops and cooks are colorbound to the black squares. Unlike a checker piece, bishops and cooks are not allowed to keep capturing after the first capture.

The object is to capture all the opponent's kings; stalemating the opponent is also a win.



Sources
D. B. Pritchard, The Classified Encyclopedia of Chess Variants, ch. 19 (https://www.jsbeasley.co.uk/encyc/175183.pdf)
Martin Gardner, Mathematical Magic Show, ch.14 (http://www.logic-books.info/sites/default/files/k07-mathemat...)
https://www.chessvariants.com/crossover.dir/cheskers.html
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cheskers
https://en.grandgames.net/online/chesckers/ (site allows online play)

name: King of the Cheese
description:
A huge yellow 3-D cheese made from thin cardboard dominates the center of the board. Players use a spinner to move their mice in turn along the predetermined path, which meanders around the board & through the cheese a number of times. The cheese has many holes which correspond to normal board 'spaces' - some holes are just large enough to accept the mice pawns without them falling out; others are larger, causing the mice to slide through the cheese and back onto the board below.

The first player to reach the hole in the cheese leading to the throne is crowned 'KING OF THE CHEESE'.

name: Totem Game
description:
"The RACK UM STACK UM game ... HEAP BIG FUN for boys and girls."

The game consists of 4 plastic card racks, 28 colored plastic interconnecting animal 'totems' and a deck of cards which have a single letter on each and spell out the various animals included in the game.

Sets of cards are color-coded, each color representing a particular animal type. Each set contains either three or four cards, depending on how many letters are required to spell the animal.

Players attempt to collect card sets which are traded for the relevant animal totem when complete. The first player to build their totem pole five animals high is the winner.
mechanics: Hand Management, Modular Board, Open Drafting, Set Collection

name: Chicken Lotto
description:
Players attempt to fill their lotto cards (5 lines, each of a particular color) with small plastic balls.

The balls are dispensed individually from inside a hollow plastic chicken by moving its tail. If a row is already full and a ball of that color is drawn, the ball is replaced in the chicken and the next player has their turn.

The first player to fill their card is the winner.

name: 40-Love Tennis
description: Roll and Hit/Move Tennis game. Singles or Doubles may be played. Each point starts with the serve, and players may then return or possibly approach a new area to return the ball. Any "5" rolled at any time (2 dice are rolled) is a winner.
mechanics: Area Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Nimm uns mit, Jim Knopf!
description: Based on the popular book by Michael Ende. One player takes the role of Jim Knopf, who wants to take as many friends as possible with him in Lukas' - who is played by another player - locomotive Emma. But even in Lummerland - the imaginary island, where the train tracks lead around - you need a ticket to ride the train. And it isn't as easy to get one of those...

name: Three Bear Family Honeycomb Hike
description: Three Bear Family Honeycomb Hike is a children's game (suggested for ages 3-6) designed to teach children colors, sizes, and the beginnings of numbers.
categories: Animals, Children's Game, Dice, Educational, Number
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement

name: Kampen om Linköping (Kunskapsspelet)
description:
Kampen om Linköping is a game about the Swedish city of Linköping. The mechanics is, roughly, a mix of Monopoly and Trivial Pursuit where most of the questions are about the city and its history.

Home Page: http://www.kunskapsspelet.se
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Stock Holding

name: ¡Oraciones Divertidas!
description: ¡Oraciones Divertidas!, or Silly Sentences in English, is a game for Spanish children, meant to teach the basics behind sentences and some basic grammar.
categories: Children's Game, Dice, Educational, Word Game
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement

name: Ídolos
description:
Ídolos is a singing game based on the American Idol/Pop Idol TV show. Players assume the role of "wanna-be pop stars", and must sing their way up, with each duel eliminating one candidate. Every round a new music style is randomly selected; after each duel, votes are casted and the one who receives less points is eliminated.

But there is another catch: every player has a secret candidate, and the main goal of the game is to make him/her win the contest. And since each grade can only be used once, there is some strategy involved in the voting process.

name: On Demand
description:
Players are leading an Enterprise. However they are not in good condition. They produce products for which there is not great demand and they have to stock those products in their warehouses. If they can't sell the products they have to dispose them if players do not set up their Enterprises "on demand" and do orientate their production on actual trends at the market.

This is a sponsored game. IBM (Switzerland) wants to show with this game how a "on demand" business works nowadays.
mechanics: Hand Management, Open Drafting, Simulation, Trading

name: Bündnis für Arbeit
description:
Description (loosely translated) from eggertspiele Website:

As members of an imaginary corporation you try to improve the initially poor state of the company.
Each player represents one of four important powers in the firm:

-) The board of directors
-) The bank
-) The staff association
-) The labor union

As a representative of one of these powers, you can influence the other powers within the company using tokens.
Your aim is to most influential power in the company. However, your increased influence can have a negative effect on the whole firm...

There's only a winner if the company is successful in all areas. In this case it's the player with the most influence.

name: Hol's der Pöppel
description:
Description (loosly translated) from the eggertspiele-Website:

Lead your ancient people to victory!

A game where you can help your luck through good tactics.

The aim is to collect counters on the unusual game board. To do that, you move your two meeples on pre-defined ways. Movement is done via cards and a constantly changing multiplier.

name: Great Lakes Pursuit
description: This trivia game is designed to encourage learning about the five Great Lakes. Game categories are Geography, Economics, Environment, Culture, Natural History and History. Players gain a puzzle piece for each category and win by completing the puzzle and answering one final question.
publishers: Ohio Sea Grant College Program, The Ohio State University

name: Spot the Intro DVD Edition
description:
This game is an off-shoot from the original Board Game version with CDs.

The DVD comes with a thousand well-known tunes, which cover famous hits from the last 50 years, plus Musicals, TV & Film themes and some Classical music, too.

The DVD is instantly ready to play, and there are picture rounds in which you have to name the bands, the singers and the musician.

It can be a team game where everybody gets a chance to take part at the same time or you can play as individuals, trying to recall where you've heard the tunes or seen that face before!

Contents:

DVD with over 2,000 clips of music and pop-artist pictures
Score Pad with Master & Team Score sheets
Answer Rule Book
Pencils
Flip Score Charts

name: Enterprise: the Elite Trading Game
description:
Enterprise is a real estate trading game, with some resemblance to Monopoly, but with elaborations. While it is designed in Australia, and uses a few Australian expressions, the content and theme are not noticeably Australian.

The playing area is a simulation of a planned city, divided into two zones : an inner Residential ring and an outer Industrial ring. The play proceeds on a circular track, with each ring containing a series of “sites”, of which two aggregate to a “subdivision”.

The ultimate objective is to “evenly develop” as many of these sites as possible, without going broke !

The Residential zone can be developed by building Cottages, Mansions, and Flats(apartments), while the Industrial zone is available for a variety of uses, represented by card “shares”( stocks). It is NOT necessary to land on a particular site to purchase it.

Players alternate between each ring according to dice throws, and pay penalties for landing on other Players’ sites. Several spaces mandate change of zone. Movement is subject to considerable randomization.

Each player receives an initial land allocation of two “subdivisions’ (two sites each of Residential and Industrial) ; plus a cash “float”. Players proceed to buy development items, initially from the bank. The pool of available items is limited, to induce competition.

The inventory comprises: Cottages 14, Mansions 10, Flats 6 ( total 30). The space available to place these items totals 24. Prices range from a low of $100 for “Cottages” to $400 for a “share” in the “Electronics” factory. More expensive items eventually provide a disproportionately higher return, but may be too expensive in the beginning of the game.

Players are able to increase the value of their holdings by increasing the capital investment on each site from a single unit up to two units and/or more valuable buildings and upgraded shares. Any site must contain only identical items, but any subdivision may contain a mix ( eg cottages and mansions on adjacent sites; or, say, “railway” shares next to “glass works”).Various bonuses accrue when sites are “double developed” and/or when sites are “evenly developed”.

These development items are available initially from a bank, but soon become tradeable between Players. Players short of cash for Landing fees may even have to trade/sell at “distress” prices.

When all a Player’s sites are “evenly developed”, Players can attempt to buy more
(vacant) land, from the bank only.

The game has several unusual features:
1. “stock’ ( houses, shares etc) can be moved from one site to another, or even “off board” until required again.
2. un-developed sites attract no landing fees (unlike Monopoly)
3. there is some limited scope for trading of rationed items above their “bank price”, as Players seek to establish “double developed” sites
4. The amount of cash available to any Player for buying at any one time is limited by certain arbitrary rules.

Possible faults :
1. The supply of in-coming cash seems too small compared to the amount leaving the Game via random penalties.
2. Arbitrary limits on Players ability to spend seem unnecessary.
3. The Game relies on a “Special Lucky Seven” rule that is easy to overlook !
4. The Rules are numbered, thus easy to reference; they are not however, arranged intuitively, and contain a few cryptic passages!
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Simulation, Stock Holding, Trading

name: Rolo-Boko
description: Unusual game consisting of six character heads and two lithographed Yo-Yo style discs. The object is to place the disc over the head and roll it it round the perimeter back to the lithographed bee start position without it falling off. That task is a pretty difficult thing to do. Characters are Jack (sailor HMS Watt.), Punch (Punch & Judy), Joey (Clown), Algy, Bertie and Colonel Bogey (cartoon or comic characters).

name: Satisfactory
description:
"Satisfactory" is a card game that bring the best and worst parts of "White Collar Work" into an interactive card game.

Each player manages a hand of cards consisting of "Hours", "Ladders", "Back-Stabbing" and "Special" cards. On each turn you pay "hours" to place down "ladder" cards trying to climb the corporate ladder to the top. Beware though, as other players can spend their hours to play "Back-stabbing cards trying to either demote your or take credit for your work.

8 random "CEO" cards alter the game dynamics by creating changes and effects to all players.

Each round is considered a week of work, and after 8 weeks the game is over. The "Worker" with the most Ladder Points wins the game.

This is a NON collectible game for 2-6 players for fast paced card action.

name: Space Marine Assault
description:
From the back of the box:

This is a tabletop battle game for two players, where you command the Space Marines, the power-armored defenders of Humanity, or the Genestealers, a strange alien race bent on the destruction of the galaxy spanning Imperium of Man.

What You Get in This Box:

- 5 Space Marines (4 with boltguns and 1 with missile launcher) for you to assemble and paint.
- 8 alien Genestealers for you to assemble and paint
- a 24-pages booklet with game rules, background information, painting and modeling instructions, and tactical advice
- a die
- 7 water-based acrylic paints
- a paint brush
categories: Collectible Components, Fighting, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame

name: Cherry Pie Fun Game
description: Subtitled "The Thrilling Pie Filling Game." Each player has a set of marbles and tries to fill in one of six sections of a plastic pie while it rotates.

name: The Phonics Game
description: This is a set of 6 educational card games based on the famous phonics learning method. Their names are In The Beginning, Silent Partners, Copy Cats, Double Trouble, Odd Balls, and Divide and Conquer.

name: Head Full of Numbers
description:
From the publisher's website:

"Kids will have math on their minds with this game for any number of players! From one child to the whole family, everyone will love the fast-paced fun. Place the three standard dice and three custom dice (with numbers 0, 1, 2, 7, 8 and 9) into the fun dice shaker then roll them out and place them into the dice tray. Set the sand timer and have the score pad ready to record the number of unique, correct equations each player makes using the numbers rolled. Equations can use simple addition or subtraction or include multiplication and division for a more challenging game."

It sounds like it's Boggle, but with math instead of words.

name: Les 12000 tours minute: Michel Vaillant
description: This vintage game is based upon the popular Michel Vaillant comic books that are also published by Dargaud. The game consists of a racetrack-board, 6 dice, 6 cars and 90 tokens.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Box-Office
description: Large Quiz game based on movies, uses similar mechanics as Trivial Pursuit (cards with several questions/answers on them). The board is organized in four parts: scenario, casting, direction and production. Each part has boxes of different colors that trigger questions about a particular topic (history of the cinema, actors, directors, films,…). The players can earn money answering these questions. The richest player is declared the winner at the end of the game.

name: Surf the World
description:
Surf the World has been created by a surfer with over 40 years of surfing experience and travels. This is the perfect game to play on flat or blown-out days, or at any time with the whole family.

Wipeout! walk the nose.... Drop in on a local.

Camp at surf spots. Collect all eight wave cards from famed surf breaks. Land on a secret spot to put yourself in front.....

Take off on a wave and surf your way around the world. During your ride, you will experience the thrills and obstacles every surfer encounters.

Learn some of the history and traditions that have helped shape this lifestyle.

Surf the World is the perfect addition to the surfing paraphernalia collected by every surfer. Once you finish the ride, you will be paddling back out for another wave. This is a game for young and old, surfers and non-surfers.

Equipment for the trip:
Game Board, 150 Question Cards, 48 Wave Cards, 6 Movers, 2 Dice, Rules

name: Herstory
description:
When you play Herstory, your travel along the game path will in many ways parallel the experiences of women throughout four hundred years of American history.

Your playing marker will be sent backward and forward on the board depending on whether an event described on your "Herstory card" was a victory or a defeat for women's advancement. You will also be sent to areas of the game board which symbolize key aspects of women's lives: home, employment, personal style, and public achievement. As American women have known both frustration and triumph in their struggle for equality, you too will progress or lose ground on the board as you learn the landmark developments of women's history, the fight for women's suffrage, and the continuing effort for fair treatment at work and at home.

The game is designed for both simple and more complex play. Those players who have had little exposure to women's history will most enjoy the simple version, which familiarizes them with details and people but does not test their knowledge. Those players who are ready for the risks (and pleasures) of a challenge will enjoy the complex version. Here questions are asked and must be answered in the course of pursuing the goal and planning game strategy.

In both game versions, the objective is to reach the end of the path where the Statue of Liberty stands as a symbol of freedom of choice and opportunity - the life goal of both women and men in America.

name: Shape of Things
description: A matching game in which each player blindly selects an object from a pouch and sees if it matches his game board. Matches can either be shape only for very young children or shape and color for young children.

name: Duck Duck Boom
description:
From the publisher:
The only thing more irresistible than the title is the addictive gameplay. Watch out for Sooperduck!

Duck Duck Boom! is a fun game that offers a few twists. Choose your target and take aim! Add a little "helper" to improve your aim. But beware, your opponents also add "helpers" that can help or hinder your efforts, and every once in a while, one of the ducks shoot back!

A great family game that also teaches basic addition and subtraction.

Contains:
30 ducks, 25 "Helper" tiles, 5 tiles of Boom!
2 Custom Dice
Rules

name: Cambridge
description:
Publisher's Description:
A challenging word game. The next step in the evolution of Hangman. A new board every time. Players write their word and begin a race to "reveal" the letters. A few twists on the same old word game. Challenging family fun.

Includes:
26 Alphabet tiles
4 "Honor" tiles
5 Player tokens

name: Sand Castles
description:
Publisher's Description:

Sand Castles is a 2-player game of flexible building strategy. Players must compete against the waves and each other. Whoever builds the most castles wins. There are always two castle designs to build. Roll the dice, collect the sand pails, towers and waves, and build your castles one "block" at a time.

Intuitive rules, a new challenge each game.

Kids love it. Great for improving spatial and planning skills.

Contains:
60 Wooden "Builder" Tiles
24 Wooden "Castle" Tiles
2 Custom dice

name: Cristallo
description:
This Heyne travel game is played on 3-piece board showing 2 identical halves with 26 round points each.

Players place 1 token per turn on the board trying to form a certain geometrical form with their pieces. When no player succeeds in reaching this, the game proceeds with movements of the token, still trying to form such a geometrical form.

But now, captures of tokens is possible by moving a token to a space, where an opposing piece is staying... but on the other half of the board! To identify the "mirrored" points, the points each have letters from A-Z.

A winning position can now also be reached when an opponent has only 3 tokens left.

name: BrainTwister
description:
BrainTwister
A fascinating game of logic and reasoning.
Two to four players compete trying to solve sequences of colorful geometric shapes.
A sequence-solving game. Players are shown a series of colored geometric shapes and they try to guess the color and shape of the sixth figure of the series. Puzzles range from the very simple to the very difficult. Depending on a die roll, players are shown only the first three, four, or five figures of the series; they then "bet" which figure will turn up sixth (once a player bets on a shape and color, no one else can make the same guess). In some cases, figures are shown one at a time, with players making bets after each unveiling. Challenging, educational, and fun.
publishers: BSM Jeux, Didacto, Orda Industries Ltd.

name: Gone Bananas
description:
"In GONE BANANAS your ID, EGO, and SUPEREGO come together on a game board that confronts you with real-life situations. You take risks and develop strategies. You will experience 'the thrill of victory and the agony of defeat.' But win or lose, you will know that you have been in a game!"

This is a fairly typical "special interest" roll-and-move game with a psychoanalytical theme and a couple unique twists.

As players move around the outer track, they collect ID, EGO, and WOW!/OW! (Superego) cards through square instructions and a Chance card mechanism. You use these cards throughout the game to buy BUTTONS and ZAPPERS, and to avoid penalties.

Linked at the corners of the outer track are four independent alternate routes, one each for the themes IS/EGO/SE and GONE BANANAS. While on these alternate paths you have the chance to earn a BUTTON (literally) of the corresponding color...but each path also entails risk and expense.

Some of the squares along the outer track where "Chance" cards are had can be "owned" by players by buying ZAPPERS with ID cards. Once bought, the squares are marked with one of the player's ZAPPER tokens. That player gets benefits for landing on the ZAPPER, while his opponents landing there have to give him a BUTTON or WOW! cards, and the opponent gets all his OW!s. Each ZAPPER location can be bought and re-bought (at a higher price) throughout the game.

The game ends immediately when one player has buttons of all four colors (representing a balanced personality) and more WOW!s than OW!s (representing positive self-worth...I guess).

The production value is first-class, as is the professional artwork on the nicely-mounted board. The bits are plastic and specially designed for the game - the player tokens are bananas on a little colored base. The cards are the only weak spot, small print on heavily-colored, cheapish card stock.

The double goal and constant shift of buttons might make this game a cut above the standard RaM fare. Keeping resource cards and buttons hidden would also increase the fun...and the chaos. I've had many of these low-volume specialty games pass through my thrifting hands, and this may be the first I actually try. The Freudian theme might wear thin early, but who knows, I might learn something about myself...or my mother.

name: Aera
description:
Aera was published by New Dimensions of Corvallis, OR, and reviewed in GAMES, April/May 1987. The games was for two players, Red and Blue, each has 6 pieces in his own color, numbered 1 to 6. There is, first a drop phase, then a movement phase with each phase being in numerical sequence.

For the dropping phase Red drops 1, then Blue drops 1. Red drops 2, then Blue drops 2, and so forth through Blue dropping 6. Now the movement phase starts. The pieces are now moved in numerical sequence. So Red moves his 1, then blue moves his 1. Red moves his 2, then blue moves his 2 and so on. In addition the pieces are started with the silver side up. When the pieces are played a second time, then they are flipped to the other side, gold, to help keep track of the sequence.

The object is to score points; one point is scored by forming a line of four of the players pieces, either orthogonal or diagonal. The first player to score six points wins.

The original pieces, according to the review, were not numbered. The "1" was a clear acrylic disc showing a circle, the "2" was an vesica piscis (oval with pointed ends), the "3" an equilateral triangle, "4" a square, "5" a pentagon, and "6" a hexagon.

name: Kariba (including Kalak)
description:
Kariba and Kalak are 2 different games by Frank Stark that come in one box. Both can be played using the same components. Kariba, the main game, is a 2 player variant inspired by the Mancala game family. Kalak is a Marbles variant, or rather, a pebble-flicking dexterity game whose arena is created by assembling the 2 piece jigsaw board in an alternative way. Kalak is mainly aimed at younger players.

KARIBA
This variation on the age-old Kalah game keeps the familiar sowing movement rules, but it introduces an alternative way to capture stones and dramatically changes the way the board is used. It also introduces new types of pebbles. They now come in 3 different colours, each with its own value, and one even with a special protective ability. The board shows 2 large scoring pits at either end of the board. Between them, 2 rows of just 4 pits are sitting side by side. Each player is assigned one row of 4 that ends in their private scoring pit. This row is the only row in which a player will place their own pieces and it should be obvious that the players move in opposite directions.

At the start, both players get a set of 25 stones that forms the supply, and these are kept beside the board. It is a mix of 3 types: 20 stones that are worth 1 point, 3 treasure stones that are worth 2, and 2 guard stones that are not only worth 3 points, but also protect all stones in a pit from capture, as long as a black stone is not caught out sitting on its own. By itself, a guard stone is equally vulnerable to capture.

In turn, players pick up 1-4 tones from supply and move them onto the board, or remove all stones from one of their own pits and move these further along the track towards the scoring pit. To move a hand of stones, the player chooses the first hand stone and drops it into the pit it would reach next on its way to the scoring pit. Then, 1 stone is dropped in each pit thereafter until a player's hand is empty. When a player manages to drop a stone into the scoring pit (here players are forced to drop the lowest value stone), it is safe and counts toward their end total. All remaining hand stones go back to supply and must start all over again. When one player has no more stones left to move, the game ends. Players add up the total points in their own pit. The loser ignores any stones left en-route on the board, but subtracts the value of the stones still in supply from this total. The player with the highest score wins, with simple tie-breakers provided.

What makes this game interesting is the way by which opposing pieces are captured. When a stone is placed in an empty hole, all opposition stones that sit beside it and are not protected by at least one guard stone are captured and are immediately added to the pit of the capturing player, boosting that player's score. The high stone total triggers the need for continued protection from capture by Guard Stones, which adds to the deliberations to be made. Guards stones will be deliberately played so they overshoot the scoring pit, ensuring their continued services as protectors of all other stones on their way to the scoring pit. However, sacrifices will have to be made, making continual forward planning a requirement for victory.

KALAK
By flipping over one side of the jigsaw board, a flat surface is revealed for the bottom half of the board, and that leaves a square of 4 small pits with 1 large one directly above it at the top. The player sits at the base of the flat surface board, and makes a smiling pebble face by placing 2 black pupil stones in the lower "eye socket" pits, 2 blue ones underneath the nose-shaped jigsaw lock to make nostrils, and by creating a smiling mouth of the remaining 8 blue stones underneath.

In phase 1, the player flicks each blue stone once, trying to reach the large target pit at the top. Only blue stones that fall into this pit can be taken into the second phase, the rest are removed. In phase 2, the player places all surviving stones in a single row on the bottom edge, including the 2 eye stones if more than 4 stones survived the first phase. Again, stones are all flicked once, but this time the player determines their end score. Each pitted stone scored one point, but player's will have to spread the stones out across all pits, as any stones that supercede the maximum capacity set for each pit in this phase are worthless. Optional rules to make it harder by using special landing restrictions for the then also more valuable eye stones, or making it easier by relaxing the set-up for phase 2 are also included.

PUBLICATION HISTORY:

2006 Kariba (including Kalak) Clemens Gerhards - deluxe wooden version - in print (last checked oct 2006)


Clemens Gerhards produces their wooden games range to high standards, and this is no exception. The 2 solid oiled beech wood board pieces slot together seamlessly, and the (minimum of) 50 semi-precious stones are colourful and elegant. A string-chord storage bag for these is provided. The whole set fits in a remarkably small box, roughly the size of a DVD box set. Frank Stark has been releasing a couple of board games each year through this smaller German imprint, after being attracted by the quality of its products.

ADDITIONAL INFO:

language skill needed: language neutral. It comes with German rules.
english translation: Clemens Gerhards has made an English translation available.
artwork: none, Clemens Gerhards games come in plain brown, ribbed cardboard boxes with the game title burnt into the lid.
awards won: none.


Note: in 2008 Clemens Gerhards published a three piece jigsaw board edition. An additional piece can be added to the original Kariba board so that a new board with two rows of six pits sitting side by side is produced. This expansion provides new tactical challenges to the game. In addition, rules for a two player game called "Cubango", a Kalaha variant that is played using the expanded board, are also included.

name: Auf die Palme, ihr Affen
description:
A three dimensional palm tree contains a number of coconuts in different colors. The goal is to climb up to the top of the palm with your ape by clever use of the coconut counters.

There are a number of chits; most show a coconut, a few an elephant. The player in turn flips a chit. If it shows a coconut, he may climb up to the next one with the same color. If it shown an elephant, he falls back a bit.

A good memory is necessary to know where the best coconuts are. The chits are moved from one area into the other each time they are displayed, and you can't use the same chip again until all of the chits have been used.

name: From the Casebook of Michael Collins' Dan Fortune
description:
From the cover "Play Dan Fortune, the one armed detective featured in the novels and stories of Michael Collins. He is a master at solving cases in which no foul play is obvious. Enjoy this exciting supplement to Ellery Queen's Mystery Magazine Game.

Uncover Hidden Evidence in these four challenging mysteries:

Would Dan Fortune turn down a beautiful women's request for help? In A Shot in the Dark, the detective assists a lady in distress.

Have the police arrested the wrong man? When there is A Death in the Greenhouse, the master detective must prove that the suspect is innocence.

When Dan Fortune vacations in Bromlee Station, three college students ask the sleuth to find their missing roommate. Are these young men overreacting, or is their friend The Missing Physicist?

Can working late at the office be fatal? Perhaps so, in The Embezzler's Revenge.
categories: Deduction, Expansion for Base-game, Murder/Mystery, Novel-based, Word Game

name: Pythagoras
description:
Ancient Greeks invent the board games (petties) and the most famous was "Pessoi" in many eras and with many differences.

Pythagoras of Samos is often described as the first pure mathematician. He is an extremely important figure in the development of mathematics yet we know relatively little about his mathematical achievements. Unlike many later Greek mathematicians, where at least we have some of the books which they wrote, we have nothing of Pythagoras's writings. The society which he led, half religious and half scientific, followed a code of secrecy which certainly means that today Pythagoras is a mysterious figure.

Pythagoras is the recreation of the Pythagorian "Pessoi".
This is a real ancient boardgame from ancient Hellas.

There is one board.
There are 2-6 players.
Each player has pawns.
Pawns must have the signs of ancient Greek letters.
Also there are three dice with ancient Greek shapes on them.
The player with the highest die roll plays first.
All pawns must enter the board make a word.

The board game Pythagoras has the following items:
1. A Colorful Board.
2. Pawns/letters different in color and shape for each of the players.
3. One to Three dice with different shapes on each one.
4. Many other items.

name: Snarps
description: Snarps are monsters who intend to scare people out of their house. As a player you control such a monster and try to get other players out of the house. This game was nominated for a Pion d'Or by the Jeux & Strategie magazine in 1991.

name: Captain Video: An Exciting Space Game
description: Based on a TV Show that ran from 1949-1957, this is a game of space exploration in which players move their four markers through the solar system. Movement is controlled by a spinner that is part of a fold-out cockpit which helps deepen the Captain Video theme.
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction, Space Exploration

name: Gebrauchtwagen Händler
description:
Description of the game from Spielbox:

Used Car Dealer - Trash or Treasure is a card game by Jorg Miethe. Buy the best used cars from the other players and create the best car collection of all. But each used car has its secrets. Perhaps there's a treasure chest in the trunk or possibly hidden accident damage. Unfortunately, you can't trust anyone in this game. In the next round, it's your chance to sell and you can then try and foist the cursed cars on someone else.

The game is based on the "Lemon Game" from business theory. The lemon game is often used to explain credit notes in the banking industry. There are two important things that a lemon game needs. One player has more information than the other and there is a greater supply than demand. The theory says that in such situations, if a player does everything right, he's making the wrong choice! BTW, the name of the game comes from 'Lemon' being slang for a car you'd rather not buy.

name: Final Lap Auto Racing Board Game
description: Final Lap Auto Racing is a dice-and-chart simulation of auto racing. The game is purchasable with sets of drivers from recent seasons or all-time greats from Formula 1, NASCAR, and Indy racing. Ratings for numerous tracks are included with the game. Drivers are rated for their ability to claim pole position, finish races, finish on the lead lap, win races, and race finish if not the winner.

name: Quakies
description:
Beautiful water lilies bloom on the pond and not only the ducks come to marvel at them. The cheeky frogs also love the water lilies and each frog tries to get hold of as many as possible before the large dragonfly comes and snatches the remaining blossoms.

Ages 4 and up.

name: Tipsi!
description: This is a four player game where the object to pick up one of four silver clay marbles at a time with a wooden spade. Players must then balance the marble as they attempt to deposit them it on top of a sort of column. The first player to successfully place four marbles is the winner.
publishers: Heritage Toy & Game Co. Ltd., Russimco Games

name: V. L. C.: Very Large Creature
description:
In the 27th century, earth faced a pollution problem of monumental proportion. To combat this problem, a new breed of genetically engineered creatures was created. These creatures could consume pollutants and scrap materials (they are also designed to be cute and machine washable). Unfortunately, some of these VERY LARGE CREATURES, or V.L.C.'s have gone rogue and are now eating cities. Can you stop them?

VLC allows you to take your stuffed animals and wage war with them against your miniatures. Because of the nature of the VLC world, any minis are usable, from fantasy, to 20th century soldiers, to futuristic vehicles and aircraft.

One player controls the V.L.C. bent on eating another city. The other player plays the cities inhabitants, militia and army forces. These troops are armed with swords, spears, rifles, ray-guns or whatever you can find in the way of army men or other minis.

Don't worry, the V.L.C.'s don't eat people, and if a V.L.C. is destroyed, its unique biology allows it to reform after the game. This makes combat a non-lethal affair.

So take that teddy bear, rabbit, Cthulu or whatever stuffed animals you have, and reek some havoc.
categories: Animals, Book, Humor, Miniatures, Science Fiction

name: Totonka!
description: This game is based upon the native American Indians. The goal is to complete your indian tent before your oponents do.

name: Grand Large
description: The goal in this nautical ship racing game (U race with sailboats) is to complete 7 stages in a race around the world as soon as possible. These stages start in St. Malo, Rio de Janeiro, Bombay, Hobart, Honolulu, Abidjan, Baltimore and the finish is again in St.-Malo.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Dschungelspiel
description:
Each player places his 2 tokens in the middle of the game board (djungle) and tries to be the first, who leaves the board with both tokens.

The djungle is covered with a grid showing 9 x 13 intercept points in 5 colors. The tokens move on the intercept points, but the die does not determine the distance of a move, but the direction! 1-4 are used for the 4 straight directions, 5 and 6 enable diagonal moves towards both sides from the starting point.

White intercept points are neutral, red and black ones reduce or increase the moving speed, yellow and blue ones enable to draw 1 of the 40 yellow or blue cards included in the game.

These cards reduce the luck factor, because they allow to change the result of the die roll in most cases (yellow card instructions must be followed immediately, blue card can be kept for later use).

name: Rocks for Sale
description:
Rocks for Sale -- asteroid mining in the lawless future.

Blurb from the rules:

"Welcome to the highly competitive industry of asteroid mining. You say you don't want to get your hands dirty, that's ok just rope them and tow them back. Many are full of precious metals like Gold, Silver and Uranium. They go for a premium on earth and you could become rich. But first you better concentrate on paying off your ship."

In Rocks for Sale, two to five (best for three to five) players fly their space ships along a pick-up and delivery circuit from the assayer's space station to the asteroid belt and back. Players tow asteroids back from the belt and sell them to the assayer, with the eventual goal of being the first to pay off their ship. But there are additional costs to running a mining ship, such as fuel, repairs and blasting charges. Mining in space can also be dangerous. Fuel leaks, overheating engines and other miners' blasting charges are only a few of the hazards an asteroid minor may face.

Will you be the first to pay off your ship? Or will cost overruns make you sink ever deeper in debt?
categories: Economic, Science Fiction, Space Exploration, Transportation
mechanics: Commodity Speculation, Paper-and-Pencil, Pick-up and Deliver, Rock-Paper-Scissors, Variable Player Powers

name: Gettysburg: Turning Point 1863
description:
The ATS game engine has been ported to the ACW period by Lieutenant Colonel Mark Johnson, author of That Body of Brave Men—The U.S. Regular Infantry and the Civil War in the West (in bookstores now) and the art is by renowned Civil War artist Alan Archambault.

ATS Gettysburg is a tactical-level game covering combat during the 3-day Battle of Gettysburg on July 1-3, 1863.

Period maps have been combined with a fresh battlefield examination by George Anderson. The maps portray Bliss Farm and MacPherson's Ridge, two intensely fought-over battle sites.

Each hex represents 50 yards of terrain and each game turn represents about 90 seconds of real time. Personnel units represent officers, couriers, color guards (6-8 men), artillery crews, and cavalry and infantry units (approximately 20-25 men). Each gun or vehicle counter represents one artillery piece or horse-drawn vehicle.

Scenarios will cover action on McPherson's Ridge on Day 1, and at the Bliss Farm over Days 2 and 3.

name: Catch a Crook Game
description:
"CATCH THE CROOK WHEN HE POPS
BE THE QUICKEST OF THE COPS"

From the box:

All eyes are on the Crook ... when will he pop? ZOOM! There he goes ... everyone grabs for him! Sharp eyes with quick reflexes are needed here. Catch the Crook when he pops then you can move your Cop along the board toward the Crook's Hideout. Be careful though, you must finish your move before he pops again. If you don't ... back you go! The first player to reach the Crook's Hideout wins the game!

A plastic figure about 5" high representing the crook is attached to a suction-loaded spring device and placed in the center of the colorful gameboard after being 'set'. Players may roll the die as many times as they wish on their turn, but if the suction device releases before the player has declared their move finished no rolls for that turn count. Whoever catches the plastic crook has the next turn.

The first player to move their plastic 'cop' along the game path from the Jail house to the Crook's Hideout is the winner of the game.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Simultaneous Action Selection, Variable Phase Order

name: Babysitter Game
description:
"If you wake the baby ... he'll YELL!"

From the box:

Everyone becomes a baby sitter when he plays this fast moving, money earning game. Each player tries to perform tasks without waking up little 'STANLEY', a light sleeper, who is sleeping peacefully in his crib. The players earn money for each task they perform while baby-sitting. Every time little 'STANLEY' jumps up and yells, players lose money.

The game comes in a huge (15" x 21" x 4") box. The large elaborate molded plastic gameboard features a complicated mechanism beneath the surface which is responsible for setting the tasks which will not be completed successfully. The gameboard depicts Stanley's room; Stanley is in his centrally located crib which is surrounded by a circle of 16 holes where the various task symbols are inserted. These holes are in turn are surrounded by a circle of 20 holes - 16 corresponding task peg holes and 4 chore holes.

Players are dealt three cards at the start of the game and draw another (or more if needed) at the start of each turn to give a total of four; these are used in gameplay to either perform tasks to earn money, or hinder other players while performing their tasks.

The active player receives the task pegs and inserts pegs into the corresponding task peg hole when required. Up to three tasks may be attempted per turn, depending on the cards held. 25 cents is awarded for the first task completed successfully, 50 cents for the second and one dollar for the third. If however Stanley pops up and 'cries', all money earned that turn is lost.

The game is over when there is no money left for distribution. Players total their earnings and the player with the highest amount is the winner.
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Hand Management, Modular Board, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Seven Years War
description:
"Seven Years War" is a two player Card-Wargame simulating the Seven Years War (1756-1763) between the English & French Alliances. Compete for influence in: Europe, North America, India, and the West Indies. Players share a common deck but with cards specific to certain players and campaigns. Victory can be achieved in Europe or the Colonies.
A complete copy of the rules can be had for free at: http://www.angelfire.com/games2/warpspawn/7YW.html
categories: Age of Reason, Card Game, Print & Play, Wargame

name: Trafalgar
description: Card game for 2 Players simulating the Naval Battle of Trafalgar 1805. Be the first to win 3 Hands in a row. Poker type mechanics. Common deck with 4 Suites: Strategy, Tactics, Morale, and Fighting. Extra card interaction to keep things interesting. Designed to be an even match. A Complete copy of the rules can be seen at: http://www.angelfire.com/games2/warpspawn/Trafalgar.html

name: Early Kings of England
description: Wargame for 2-5 Players. England circa 800-1000 AD. Players can choose to be: Vikings, Anglo-Saxons, Welsh, Scots, or Picts. Area Map. Racial Special Abilities. No Dice. Simple rules for Unit recruitment & Movement. Players share a common deck which is used to resolve Battles. Card types include: Warrior, Weapon, Armor, Fort, & Siege. Conquer the most territory in 10 turns. Complete copy of the rules available at: http://www.angelfire.com/games2/warpspawn/EKE.html

name: Sonic The Hedgehog Card Game
description: This easy-to-play card game has two ways to win - are you an expert enough to win both ways? The object of the game is to be the first player to win the most Gold Ring cards OR to win all six Chaos Emerald cards before all of the six Zone cards are played. Comes packaged with a score pad and 108 cards with tray. For ages 6 and Up.
categories: Animals, Card Game, Video Game Theme

name: Milt Larsen's Magic Castle Card Game
description: This game is produced and sold by The Academy of Magical Arts, an organization devoted to the art of stage magic, based at The Magic Castle in Hollywood, CA. The game is named for Milt Larsen, a writer on the game show "Truth or Consequences," who helped restore an old Victorian home into the Magic Castle. The object of the game is to be the first player to match your six squares on the game board with matching cards.

name: All American Baseball
description:
Players sit side-by-side facing the bottom of the game board. Each player has a dial on the board with 6 possible Batting options and 6 possible Pitching options. Cupping their hands over their dial to keep their selection hidden from the opponent until both players reveal their selection simultaneously, the player at bat sets their dial to one of the Batting options (A-Steal, B-Sacrifice, C-Hit or Steal, D-Hit and Run, E-Ready and Cautious (to hit if pitch looks good), F-To Hit (swing hard)) and the player on the mound selects one of the Pitching options (1-Fast Ball, 2-Curve In and Over, 3-Corner Clipper, 4-Bad Ball Break Away, 5-Pitch-Out, 6-Throw to Base). For every bases situation from No-One-On-Base to Bases Loaded there is a separate reference card conveniently held together in small notebook binder fashion. Also, there are three pitcher cards that need to be consulted for some play results, and which can be used for a little more realism about varying pitcher abilities.

For the result of the play dice are rolled to see if the pitch is a ball or strike, or if a play action results. For example, with No-One-On-Base, and the Batter sets their dial to F-To Hit Hard, and the Pitcher sets their dial to 2-Curve, and a 7 is rolled on the dice, the players would look at the No-One-on-Base card in the F-2 Column with dice roll 7 (F-2-7) and the result might be a ball, strike, hit batter, wild pitch, or one of 150 numbered plays (1-150) resulting, such as Ground Out, Fly Out, Single, Double, Triple Home Run, Error, Rain Delay (or rain out), or whatever. There's even a Triple Play possibility -- with at least two runners on base -- but because that is a rare play it may rarely if ever happens.

The game appears to be self published in 1962. Similar to Cadaco's All-star baseball, but without cards for individual players. Roll dice to determine play outcome.

Includes:
o Gameboard baseball field with Pitching/Batting Dial, and the field can be used to place markers to indicate runners on base (or baseball player miniatures not included).
o Pitch Result Card for each runner situation (No one on base, Runner on 1st, Runner on 2nd, Runner on 3rd, Runners on 1st and 2nd, Runners on Second and 3rd, Bases Loaded).
o Text of 150 play results printed on the inside of the game box top, and which is easily propped up behind the gameboard baseball field (like and outfield wall) where each of the 150 play results can easily be read.
o Three pitcher cards (Rookie to Ace) for use with some hit-pitch results
o Two dice

All American Baseball is a fun head-to-head game with balls and strikes and 150 potential plays every pitch depending on Pitch/Hit selections made by players and a dice roll. It does not include a lefty-righty factor, real or fictional players or abilities, speed, defense, or pitcher fatigue; the fun comes from trying to outwit your opponent with your hidden pitch and hit choices each pitch, and for the great number of potential play outcomes that are relevant to whether or not runners on on base(s).

name: The Hamster That Ate the World
description:
General Stormgunden chewed on his cigar and grumbled under his breath. "Damn hamster has broken through our left flank," he finally told the president as the two of them watched the new footage on the television.

Stormgunden watched as the small man next to him paled at the thought of the monstrous beast rampaging about the country.

"Nothing left now to stop the beastie, he will be in the capital by nightfall," the vice president said over his fourth scotch.

The man was drunk, Stormgunden thought as he bit down on his cigar once more, twisting it about in his mouth.

"We have only one hope sir," he spoke once more, turning to the president, "Nukes!"

This is the newest Mini-game from Bad Baby Productions, The Hamster That Ate The World. Some mad scientist, somewhere, for some mad reason has injected a small hamster, Mr. Chip, with who knows what. Now the hamster has escape, grown and gotten hungry. It seems that only the cities of the world can feed the ravenous hamster now and he's heading this way.

A fast game of hamster rage and human desperation, can you stop the 200 foot hamster before he crushes the cities of mankind under his huge hamster feet. Can you play Mr. Chip, and try to end the rule of man, ushering in a new hamster dominated age.
categories: Fighting, Horror, Humor, Modern Warfare, Print & Play

name: Robot Jocks
description:
Lopez struggled to regain his balance after the servo of missiles slammed into his robot. The sheer force of the missiles combined explosions nearly knocked him to his knees. Even so, his skill at the controls allowed him to not only stabilize the massive robot, but to even bring himself into a good position to use his own heavy weapon.

With a flick of his trigger finger, Lopez's robot fired the massive fusion cannon which belched forth a deadly stream of super heat gas. Johnson's robot took it full in the face and fell backwards, crashing to the arena floor with a might thud.

The crowd roared as Lopez took his victory lap around the arena, one more foe defeated by his superior robot driving skills and weaponry.

This is Bad Baby's latest Mini-game, Robot Jocks. Take your mighty robot's weapon systems into the national arena and fight other robots. Try to out maneuver, out fight and just plain out last your foe in this unique, and fun, card based game.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Open Drafting, Variable Player Powers

name: Rise and Fall of the 7 Civil Warlords
description:
This is a area movement card driven wargame set during the emergence of the Han dynasty and the fall of the Chin dynasty.

90 counters 32 cards.

name: Loudmouth
description: The Game of Outrageous Discussions. Based on the Morton Downey, Jr. TV Show. Players debate and discuss hot-button political and social issues.
categories: Humor, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Party Game

name: OleO
description:
This game plays like UNO with dice: Players race to empty their hands. The first player who managed this gets score points for the cards left in the opponents hands.
In turn, players attempt to play a card by matching its color or symbol to the topmost card on the discard pile. The player may only discard a suitable card if he succeeds in throwing a special combination of three dice: e.g. Street (2-3-4), High-Score (sum more than 15), Sandwich (1-5-1) or OleO (3-3-3). If unable to play, players draw one card from the draw pile.
The player who got the most points after a specific number of turns wins the game.

name: The Crypt
description:
The Crypt: A Solitaire Game

Published in TSR's R.I.P. Comic #7 (Part 3 of 4 of the R.I.P. Brasher Comic Module)

Consists of 30 tiles you cut out from the comic. You need to provide a token to represent you on the board, 1D6, and paper and pencil to keep track of your character and the number of turns spent in the tomb.

"In this solitaire game, you are the explorer, seeking treasure in old tombs. Each turn, more of the crypt is revealed as you travel along the dark and dusty tunnel. Each game is different, and danger lurks around every corner.

The object of this quest is the recovery of the Pharaoh's Scepter."

Place the starting tile face up. "The character moves through the various rooms and corridors depicted on those tiles. Each turn, when the character wants to move in a direction not yet explored, a tile is picked at random from the unused pile and placed in the direction the player is moving. Make sure the corridors line up with each other. If there is more than one possible way to align the corridors, the orientation is up to the player. The token representing the player is then moved to the new section.
